debate.para: Address-in-Reply .

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the following Address-in-Reply to His Excellency the Governor-General's Speech he agreed to : -
To His Excellency the Governor-General - Mat it it.ease Your Excellency:

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

speech.para: There are many reasons why I am pleased to have the honor of moving the motion

I have just submitted, and chief among them is the knowledge that we have at last in power a Commonwealth Government that will uphold the principles of democracy, and legislate on a humanitarian basis in the interests of all sections of the community. The advent, of this Government is in more .than one sense historically important, since it is the first Labour administration to sit in the Federal Capital of Australia, and the first to hold office since the termination of the great war. It is approximately fourteen years since the Fisher Labour Government held office, but there are many of us who well remember the good work which it performed, aud therefore appreciate the re-entry of Labour to administer the affairs of the Commonwealth. I can say without fear of contradiction that there has never been a federal ministry more earnest and sincere and more honestly desirous of administering the affairs of the Commonwealth in the best interests of the nation than the Fisher Government was. To-day we have in power a replica of that administration. I am convinced that it will uphold the splendid example set by the Labour Government of fourteen years ago, and legislate not on behalf of sectional interests, but for the protection of all.

For years every conceivable act of political trickery was practised by our political opponents in order to keep Labour out .of office. Aided by a large majority of the great newspapers of Australia they vilified and misrepresented Labour from one end of Australia to the other. I remember the leaders of the Bruce-Page Government telling the people prior to the 1925 election that Australia was on the verge of a revolution, and that the Labour party wished to dispense with constitutional government. There was, of course, not the slightest justification for such statements. Again during the 1925 election, when the great waterside trouble was in progress, the representatives of the Bruce-Page Government assured the people of Australia that if they were granted a further term of office, Johnson and Walsh would be deported, that peace and harmony would prevail, and that the country would be governed according to law. The political cry of our opponents at that time was for "law and order." The people, however, have come to see that they were tricked. The result of the last -general election shows that at last they realized that what they had been told by our opponents was untrue, and as a result of this awakening a Labour government is in power to-day. The supporters of the Bruce-Page Government promised all sorts of reforms, for which the people looked in vain, and when that government endeavoured to put the clock back 25 years by attempting to destroy the principle of arbitration, and thus deprive the workers of their only means of receiving fair treatment the electors expressed their disapproval in the most decisive fashion. During the last election campaign no side issues such as communism or bolshevism were raised as on previous occasions. For the first time in many years the people were free to give their decision on one broad issue, stripped of political trappings, and their verdict was a triumph for democracy as against an autocracy.

The task before the present Government is tremendous. How gigantic it is few persons fully realize. It is not my desire to hit a man when he is down, but [ cannot refrain from saying that the previous Government has left matters in such a state that it will be some time before the present administration will be able to make real progress. Unfortunately, it is unable to start from scratch; it commences with the handicap of the previous Government's maladministration. Last year the then Treasurer (Dr. Earle Page) informed the people of Australia that there was an accumulated deficit of £5,000,000, and as five months of the current financial year have elapsed it will be an extremely difficult task for the Government to accomplish what it desires during the present financial year. The speech which His Excellency delivered to Parliament yesterday gives an indication of the course which the Government intends to pursue, but a more detailed outline of its legislative programme will be given early next year. It will be admitted that the Government is pursuing the right course and that it is its desire to work in the interests of the community generally.

While in power the Nationalist Government was always advocating industrial peace, but its one idea of the way in which industrial peace should be brought about was that the worker should always make a sacrifice. In 1928 the Bruce-Page Government passed an arbitration bill containing many iniquitous clauses aimed at the workers, but within twelve months it had to admit that this legislation was quite ineffective. It then endeavoured to scrap the whole system of arbitration. I am extremely pleased that the present administration intends to* bring down legislation to improve our present system of conciliation and arbitration. We shall not have industrial peace until equity and justice prevail, and we look to the Conciliation and Arbitration Court for justice for the workers. I sincerely hope that the strenuous efforts now being made by the Government to settle the coal dispute will meet with success. I do not desire to deal extensively with that matter at this juncture; but the trouble is so serious that I urge the Government to take steps - drastic, if necessary - to put an end to the suffering and misery that now exist as a result of the lockout. I have visited the coal-fields, and I know precisely what is happening there. I have seen helpless little children going to school lunchless, and forced to have recourse to the soup kitchens provided by charity in. order that they might keep body and soul together.

talk.start.para: - Whose fault is that?

- The honorable senator knows whose fault it is. When his Government was in power, it refused to make any endeavour to compel the coal-owners to settle the dispute. To-day, the Nationalist Government of New South Wales is doing little more to bring about peace in the industry. According to the views of honorable senators opposite, there is only one method by which the dispute may be settled, and that is by the worker making further sacrifices.

speech.para: I am sure that everybody will be pleased to learn that further restrictions are to be placed upon the introduction of foreign migrants into Australia. It is useless to deny that foreigners are being employed in this country to the detriment of Australians. Hundreds of thousands of pounds are sent out of the country annually by these foreigners. Every rational person must realize the futility of protecting Australian industries if, at the same time, we import foreigners to manufacture the articles that we need. The Federal Labour Government will endeavour to make operative an effective tariff that will be in the interests, primarily, of Australians and Britishers. If any benefits remain to be distributed, the foreigners may have their share. "We should certainly not encourage the introduction of foreign migrants while our own countrymen are out of employment. I have nothing against those foreigners, other than that their standard of living is not ours. After years of toil and sacrifice, Australians have established a standard of living of which we are all proud, and which we cherish to such an extent that we are not prepared to permit it to be lowered.

talk.start.para: - How can it be lowered when we have arbitration court awards?
- On very good authority I have been informed that foreigners are being employed in Australia at less than award wages.
- Yet the honorable senator's Government allows that state of affairs to continue.

- The honorable senator will realize that it is necessary to confirm the information before taking action. The trouble is caused by these foreigners being ignorant of the industrial conditions prevailing in Australia. Many of these men know nothing of arbitration court awards, and their ignorance is being taken advantage of by some of the people whom Senator Foll represents. The Federal Government gives practical assistance to the country by making substantial monetary advances to the States in order that an extensive system of main roads may be constructed, and I hope that steps will be taken to ensure that all the materials used in the construction of those roads shall be of Australian origin. It will be agreed that it is regrettable that we have to import motor cars, but that it verges on tragedy if we have to import the material with which to construct the roads on which those motor cars run. I trust that the Government will be able to devise some scheme to relieve existing distress produced by unemployment. There is no greater crime to society than to allow helpless women and children to suffer the pangs of hunger, particularly in such a young country as ours, where the natural resources are illimitable. It is pathetic that, after a reign of fourteen years, Nationalist governments have left the country in such a deplorable condition.
- Does the honorable senator contend that the Federal Government is wholly responsible for all this distress ?

- No ; but I hold that to Nationalist governments must be attributed the blame for most of the distress that now reigns in Australia. I may be wrong, but it is- my conviction, and apparently that of the constituents who sent me here, that a government should do something in the interests of the people it represents. It should be realized that the backbone of a country is its flesh and blood, and that something should be done for the people who made great sacrifices during the Great War to keep this country safe for democracy. The people are entitled to all that it is humanly possible to give them, and a government should honour that obligation. If a government fails in its duty to the people it must expect to be thrown out of office. And that was the fate of the late Federal Nationalist Government.

speech.para: I trust that honorable senators will realize the seriousness of Australia's position, the extent of the problems which confront this Government, and the great handicap under which it labours. No other Federal government came into power at a more unfavorable time. On every hand it is faced with want and hunger - with a great army of unemployed. Within a few weeks it has achieved wonders, and has encouraged many employers to cease dispensing with the services of their employees. That in itself is some justification for its existence, and goes to prove that it is sincere and earnest in its endeavour to ease unemployment and to encourage the prosperity of our industries in order thai they will be able in the near future to provide work for more of our own people. 1 am confident that this Labour administration will warrant the trust reposed iu it by the people, and I solicit the help of all honorable senators in the task that is involved in straightening out the present chaotic state of affairs. If we all put our shoulders to the wheel and assist we shall again place the country upon the plane to which it was raised by the Fisher government over fourteen years ago. It is the intention of this Government to continue where the Fisher government left off, and, if given a fair chance, it will undoubtedly do as that government did - leave the country with a surplus instead of the tremendous deficit under which it now groans.

talk.start.para: . - I have much pleasure in seconding the motion moved by Senator Dooley that an address ' be presented to His Excellency the Governor-General in reply to the speech with which he opened Parliament yesterday. That pleasure is intensified by the fact that as the result of the overwhelmingly favorable vote cast for Labour candidates at the recent general election we have now on the Treasury bench of the Commonwealth Parliament, a Labour Government in control of the affairs of this great nation, meting out justice to all and giving favours to none. [ congratulate our worthy and able leader, Mr. Seullin, on being the first Labour Prime Minister to assume control of the Government in the National Capital, Canberra; and in this regard, I extend my congratulations also to his worthy and able team of Ministers. I trust that their stay in office will be prolonged. As to their success I have no doubt whatever.

speech.para: It is fitting that I should tender special congratulations to Senator Daly, my colleague from South Australia, on his accession to the high and honorable office of Vice-President of the Executive Council, and Leader of the Government in the Senate. In his hands and in those of my old friend and colleague, Senator Barnes, to whom I also tender my congratulations, the destiny of the Government in this chamber will be safe and the business of the Senate will be well and worthily carried out.

Not only is the return of a Labour Government to office a fact of historical importance; it represents one of the greatest triumphs of the Labour movement. For fourteen years Labour has existed in the shades of opposition, beset by many great storms that have from time to time darkened the political horizon. After being called upon to suffer an almost withering attack from within its own ranks, it was faced with the defection of many stalwarts of the movement, who, having sharpened their wits by association with Labour, and in the service of their former ideal, thereafter sought by all means at their command to encompass its destruction. But the movement has weathered all storms, and today, as the result of the first election since 1914 that has been decided upon real political issues, it is in power in another place with a big majority. The people, when given the opportunity, not only displayed their confidence in the Labour movement; they also intimated in no uncertain way that the federal system of arbitration should be retained, and with it the Australian standard of living. This standard, as we know, gives a measure of comfort to the masses, those who bear the heat and burden of the day, those who do the useful work, those who delve in the mines for riches or work in the fields and paddocks to foster production, or keep the wheels of industry turning. It is the aim of the Labour movement to give to those who produce the wealth of the nation a full and just share in the apportionment thereof ; and it is a healthy sigu that the people of this generation of Australians have recognized the efforts of those great democrats of the old days who pioneered the Labour movement, and, facing tremendous odds, nailed to the mast- head of this young country the banner of civil and economic freedom. I take this opportunity to pay a tribute not only to those worthy pioneers who still remain loyal to our cause, but also to the countless thousands who constitute the rank and file of the movement for the yeoman service they rendered at the last election. The gibes of our critics during the years we were in opposition, have been well answered by the people of Australia. The movement has emerged from its testing time fitter, better and stronger than ever.

As to the task confronting the Government, I have no illusions. The banner of civil and economic freedom is still at the masthead, but that for which it stands is very far from realization so far as a big body of the people are concerned. It will be one of the greatest tasks of the Government to bring that freedom nearer to the homes of the people, but first of all the Government must dispose of the many unpleasant legacies handed down by its predecessors in office. Among these are widespread unemployment with its attendant suffering, which has been so well described this afternoon by Senator Dooley, an empty Treasury, a deficit of approximately £5,000,000, and depreciation in our primary and secondary industries, which must give all thinking persons ample ground for concern. It. cannot be said that the previous Government upon acceptance of office was fettered by an inheritance such as this. Rather was the reverse the case. Upon coming into office it found in the Treasury a surplus of £7,400,000, little unemployment, and prosperity in our primary and secondary industries. It is not my intention to indict the late government for having altered all this. It has already been arraigned before the bar of public opinion and found guilty by the jury of the people of the Commonwealth. Its punishment is that its stewardship has been handed over to another government - the problems confronting Australia have been entrusted to other hands for solution.

The speech with which His Excellency the Governor-General was pleased to open Parliament yesterday, disclosed not only a desire for action on the part of the Government, but also the fact that steps have already been taken by it to deal with the existing unemployment which is probably one of the greatest problems confronting Australia to-day.

talk.start.para: - But unemployment is world-wide to-day.

- The fact that it is world-wide, does not mean that it is incapable of solution. Nor does it connote that a government earnestly and honestly anxious to grapple with the problem, cannot solve it. In how many countries of the world can Senator

debate.para: Thompson attribute existing unemployment to the movement which is represented by the Government occupying the Treasury bench in the Commonwealth Parliament at the present time? My friend's silence shows that there was no point in the interjection he made. The Government has placed the unemployment problem in the forefront of its policy. It proposes to tackle it in what I consider the best way of dealing with it, and that is by curtailing migration. We are told by His Excellency the Governor-General that a communication has already been forwarded to the Imperial Government seeking relaxation from the assisted passage provisions of the migration agreement with Great Britain. I trust that the Imperial Government will accede to the request, because I can conceive no worse policy than one which encourages work seekers to migrate to a country where the reservoir of labour is already overfull. If we induce people to come here under those conditions, it is distinctly unfair to them, because their entry can only be followed by one of two results - they must either join the army of workless or displace others already in employment. Irrespective, therefore, of whatever government may be in power, it should be an accepted fact that no migrants should be assisted to come to Australia until proper provision has been made for their absorption in our community.

During its term of office the late Government spent approximately £2,000,000 on migration activities. The bulk of the expenditure represents passage money for the 160,000 migrants who were brought to Australia during the period. It must be obvious that had there been no assisted migration during that period, there would be little or no unemployment in Australia to-day.

talk.start.para: - If my friends of the Opposition will tell me how we can gain by bringing to this country a person who is not. in the position to pay his own passage, when we already have here people for whom we cannot find employment, I shall be prepared to concede the point. But until they can do so, I repeat what I have already said in this chamber, that it is not a wise policy. I am pleased the people of Australia have endorsed that attitude, because this question was undoubtedly one of the turning factors in the recent elections. Would it not have been better if that £2,000,000 had been diverted into channels, controlled by either the Commonwealth alone or the State Governments in co-operation with the Commonwealth, which would have assisted the primary and secondary industries of the country to extend their activities and thus absorb more workers? As it is, the money which has been expended has merely brought to Australia a number of competitors with Australians in an already overcrowded labour market. The interjections of honorable senators opposite give colour to the suspicion that behind the policy of the late government was a desire to create a surplus supply of labour, which, together with the abolition of the Arbitration Court, would have resulted in a lowering of the Australian standard of living.

debate.para: Many of the migrants who came to Australia expecting that the promises made to them prior to their departure from their homeland would be realised have been sadly disillusioned; they are now included in the ranks of the workless in this country. It is true that some migrants have secured employment in Australia, but only by displacing others. The suspension of assisted migration will do much to solve the great problem of unemployment. The Premier of South Australia has attempted to take the Federal Government to task in this connexion. If there is one responsible public man in Australia who should remain silent on the subject of unemployment it is the Honorable R. L. Butler, the Premier of South Australia, for that State is in the unenviable position of having the highest percentage of unemployed workers of any of the Australian States.

talk.start.para: - That is an inheritance from a Labour government.

- The honorable senator's interjection shows how little consideration he has given to the facts. Only this morning I looked up the Federal statistician's figures relating to unemployment at the time that the

debate.para: Labour Government in South Australia relinquished office in March, 1927, and I found that four per cent, of the workers in that State were then unemployed. To-day over 14 per cent, of the workers of that State are out of employment.

talk.start.para: - The effects of Labour administration in that State are only now being realized.

- I again remind the honorable senator that before interjecting he should make sure of his facts. The chief factor contributing to the present unsatisfactory position in South Australia was the huge public works policy of a previous Liberal administration, known as the Railways Rehabilitation Scheme. That Government, instead of spreading the work over a number of years, endeavoured to complete it in a comparatively short time, with the result that it attracted to South Australia some of the surplus labour from the other States. When the work was completed large numbers of men were thrown out of employment.
- Did not the Labour party in South Australia approve of that railways rehabilitation scheme?

- It did not. The Labour Government on assuming office would have curtailed the scheme, but the work was then so far advanced that that action was not practicable. It is true that it could have refused to finance the scheme, but that would have meant that a number of railway lines which had been torn up would have been left in such a state that trains could not have run over them; bridges would have been left partially built; and new structures to take the place of engine sheds and workshops which had been demolished would have been left in various stages of completion. To have left the railways in that condition would have been to act more foolishly than to complete the original scheme.

debate.para: Not only should the admission into Australia of foreign migrants be discouraged, but steps should also be taken to deal effectively with those already here. Under the Federal Aid Roads Scheme the Commonwealth makes available to the States large sums of money for road construction. While I am not aware of the position in all the States, I know that, as a result of the insistence by the late Government that the contract system should be adopted in connexion with such works, large numbers of southern Europeans have been employed by road contractors in South Australia, to the detriment of genuine Australians. Men in a position to know have informed me that some hundreds of such foreigners are employed on road construction works in that State. One contractor, who is his own foreman, employs a gang of 22 men, all of whom are foreigners. Another contractor is himself a southern European, and, naturally, the men working under him are also foreigners.

talk.start.para: - Those are not Federal, but State, contracts.

- The Federal Government insisted on the contract system being adopted in connexion with such works, notwithstanding that the State government had in existence a fine roadmaking organization which was doing better work than is now being done by contractors. Honorable senators opposite cannot evade their responsibility by saying that those contracts were let by the State government. The Federal Government, which paid the piper, could have called the tune. In this class of work Australian and British workmen should be given preference over foreigners, and I hope that that policy will soon be pur into operation by the present Government.

debate.para: The Governor-General's Speech indicates that financial matters will engage the immediate attention of the Government. Naturally, it does not contain particulars of the policy to he adopted, for that is a matter which will be explained when the budget is presented and the Estimates come under consideration ; but, knowing what previous Labour governments have done, I have no doubt that the present administration will not only grapple with the financial problems confronting the Commonwealth, but that it will also discharge the existing mortgage, and bring about a surplus. History will repeat itself.

talk.start.para: - How is all this to be done ?
- When confronted with difficult problems the late Government endeavoured to escape its obligations by creating leaning posts, such as royal commissions and boards of inquiry.
- What about the Hibble tribunal? Is that not a commission ?

- The term of office of that government was notable for the number of such leaning posts which were created. I am pleased that the members of the new Government propose to discontinue the practice followed by their predecessors in office. In future there will be greater co-ordination between the Development and Migration Commission and other government departments without in any way impairing the efficiency of any of them. The Government will not create separate boards to do work which can more effectively be carried out by existing departments. With that, I think, the people of Australia will wholeheartedly concur, and, after the scheme has been launched, it will, I am sure, be responsible for a considerable saving, and bring about that result concerning which Senator Payne appears to be so anxious.

debate.para: The next question that calls for consideration is the condition of our primary and secondary industries. To improve our position we must aim at increased production, and provide better facilities for the marketing of our products. No government should countenance any avoidable drop -in the price of Australia's primary production. The efforts of all governments should be directed towards increasing the yields and the stabilization of prices. During the regime of the late Government - for the last decade, as a matter of fact - there was a considerable increase in the area under production; but, unfortunately, that increase did not connote an increased production in the same ratio. On the contrary, there has been ' a substantial decline in the Australian ' wheat yield in recent years. It may be argued that this is beyond the control of any government - that it is due, in the main, to variations in climate, fluctuations in price, and other causes.

talk.start.para: - Were we responsible for the dry seasons?

- Although, propitious precipitations have deluged most of the drought areas of Australia since the advent of this Government, I am not going to be so unkind as to imply that the late Government was responsible for the 'drought season which preceded the rains. I do not suggest that the Bruce-Page Administration had any control over the weather; but I do emphasize that governments can control the opening up of areas for wheat-growing purposes, and I do say that State governments of the same character as that which recently occupied the federal treasury bench have been responsible for the settlement of wheat-farmers in areas where the margin of safety, as regards rainfall, is very narrow. Thus we are faced with the position that, despite huge expenditure on public works in providing facilities for new settlers, large numbers of primary producers, after spending some of the best years of their life in trying to develop their holdings, have been obliged to leave them without any reward for their years of toil.

debate.para: Two illustrations of the truth of my statement are to be found in South Australia and Victoria. In those States successive Liberal or Nationalist governments have consistently overlooked large areas of country with an assured rainfall, suitable for practically all kinds of mixed farming, and have opened up for settlement land in districts with -an insufficient rainfall. These areas have been developed at a huge cost to the taxpayers in those States.

talk.start.para: - What particular area has the honorable senator in mind?
- The northern mallee iri Victoria and portions of Eyre Peninsula and the- northern Murray valley in South Australia.
- Does the honorable senator say that a Nationalist Government in Victoria was responsible for opening up the northern mallee?
- Yes, and the results have been most disastrous tn the people concerned.
- I heard that story during the election campaign and wondered who was responsible for it. Now I know.

- The parties which have been opposed to Labour for so long have been masquerading under so many different banners in recent years that it is impossible to say, at the moment, by what names all. State non-Labour governments were known.
- The honorable senator's statement is merely an election " tarradiddle."

- The Leader of the Opposition -may call it an election " tarradiddle " if he wishes to do so ; but it is a fact that State governments similar in character to the late Federal Government have been responsible for the settlement of large areas of country with a doubtful rainfall in the States mentioned.
- Does the bonorable senator condemn the land on Eyre Peninsula ?
- Not the whole of it.
- Then why complain? It, is proving the salvation of the State this year.

- I admit that there is a large area of good land on that Peninsula, with an assured rainfall, and in the years to come that territory should produce a much greater cereal crop than it has up to the present. But in recent years other districts with a scanty rainfall have been opened up. Railway facilities have been provided and heavy expenditure incurred in other public works, but settlers who took up land four, five or six years ago are still waiting for a return on their expenditure of capital and labour. I refer particularly to the Buckleboo ai-ea. If the honorable senator will read some of the reports presented to the South Australian Parliament concerning that settlement, he will have some idea of the amount paid in drought relief to keep farmers on the land there. To counteract the evil effects of this unwise policy of land settlement, there should be co-operation between the Federal and State Governments for the repurchase of land in large estates suitable for closer settlement in districts with an assured rainfall. If this is done settlers who take up that land will have reasonable certainty of some return, and since railways, roads and other public works have been, provided, the expenditure necessary for the settlement of a given number of people should be considerably reduced. It should be possible to bring such areas under production at little or no public expenditure, and in addition the return on expenditure for existing public works should be considerably increased. This is u matter in which I have taken a great deal of interest, but as I have spoken upon it on a former occasion, I do not wish now to reiterate what I then said. [ strongly urge the Government to see that the necessary tests for suitability are made before further lauds are opened up for settlement. If we are to secure an increase in the volume of our production, we shall have to insure a closer settlement of all those areas with an assured rainfall. I noted with pleasure, a statement made by the Leader of the Senate (Senator Daly) yesterday to the effect that the Government proposes to extend the policy of applying science to our primary industries.
- Did not the late Government do something in that direction?

- I freely admit that it did, but there is a vast field for an extension of that work. We must realize this when we remember that, as regards the yield per acre, Australia is twenty-fourth on the list of the principal primary producing countries of the world. There are two ways in which our position in this respect may be improved. The first is by the restriction of wheat-growing in areas with a doubtful rainfall, and the second is by increased production per acre in cultivable areas with an assured rainfall. This increase in yield would be made possible by the eradication of pests, and the application of scientific methods to production.

debate.para: I come now to the question of marketing. In my opinion the late Government did not give sufficient attention to this important matter. It is brought home to us more forcibly each year that, as regards the sale of their exportable surplus, our primary producers are at the mercy of speculators. An attempt has been made to formulate a pooling system for the co-operative handling of our wheat. It has been attended with some success, but I believe that to secure to the Australian wheat farmers that full measure of justice which they have a right to expect, it will be necessary to establish an all-Australian pool, into which farmers will be compulsorily drafted. I do not say that the Government should, willy nilly, pass legislation to compel our farmers to pool everything. What I suggest is that, as regards the disposal of surplus wheat, our growers should have an opportunity to decide by ballot whether or not they approve of such a proposal, and the Government should indicate that if their decision is in favour of a compulsory pool, it would assist them to the fullest possible extent. Any system, to be complete, must have some outside backing, because in the early days of any co-operative scheme it would be impossible for the farmers themselves to provide the finance.

talk.start.para: - I suppose the honorable senator admits that an effective cooperative system would bring about the same result?

- Yes. But what would be the price if it were not for the operation of the co-operative system, which in Australia to-day act3 as a policeman to private purchasers who are compelled to make their offers substantially on the basis of what they anticipate the pool will be able to pay ? If they did not do so they would not be able to buy wheat at all.
- What are thiadvantages of a compulsory pool?
- In Australia they would be similar to the advantages derived by the farmers of Canada from an all-Canadian pool.
- There i3 not an allCanadian pool.
- There is an all-Canadian pool; but all the Canadian wheat is not placed" in the pool.
- There is not an allCanadian pool. They have separate pools.
- They have separate pools for the respective provinces with a central form of control. In this connection I quote the following from the Sydney Morning Herald, published this morning^-"

debate.para: Vancouver, Nov. 19.

Co-operation between the Canadian Wheat Pool and the Farmers' National Grain Corporation of the United States is a possibility, in the opinion of Mr. Alexander Legge, chairman of the Federal Farm Board at Washington. The pool and the Farm Board have exchanged friendly greetings.

Mr. Legge said that the board had also had correspondence with Argentina, but in view of present conditions it was not possible for wheatgrowers in the United States and Argentina to co-operate. Mr. Legge previously made it clear that as far as the organization of United States producers was concerned there would be nothing but co-operation with the Canadian organization. Such cooperation, it is suggested, would be most informal. Just as two industrial corporations might have a gentleman's agreement in regard to price and division of markets, so the wheat organizations might arrange their affairs.

It is felt in the United States that the Canadian growers are in a very advanced position. While some Argentine producers are considering the co-operative idea, it has not been developed as in North America.

Commenting on this aspect, Mr. Legge said: "If the Argentine growers organized either on the basis of the Canadian pools or what we ave trying here, the Western Hemisphere would be in a position to meet, on an equal basis, the concentrated buying effect of consuming nations."
Why quibble over the terms " co-operative marketing " and " pooling ".

talk.start.para: - There is no Canadianwide pool in Canada.

- No, but there are provincial pools controlled by a Canadian-wide organization. A few weeks ago-, when, there was a tremendous financial slump in Wall-street, the Canadian pool was able to stabilize the wheat market to a considerable extent. It not only refused to sell at the panic values created by the slump, but was able to purchase quantities of wheat offering at panic prices. I have also an interesting extract from the report of a debate in the House of Commons on 29th or 30th October, published in the South Australian Advertiser, a portion of which reads -

quote.para: WHEAT DUMPING.
German Chain in London. Helped by Bounty.
London, October 30.
In the House of Commons to-day, Sir Edward Hiffe (Conservative) called attention to the dumping of German wheat and other cereals in this country.

debate.para: Se moved that immediate steps be taken by the Government to counteract this injurious effect upon British agriculture. He said the German subsidy on wheat was approximately 13s. (id. per quarter, and in that way the British farmer could be under-sold.

Great Britain offers a market for a substantial portion of our export surplus of wheat. I realize that a pooling system or co-operative marketing, cannot preventthe German government from subsidizing its wheat producers, but we can place our Australian selling agency on a better basis. The report continues -

quote.para: Dr. C. Addison, UnderSecretary for Agriculture, replying to the debate, said there was unanimity about the condition of British agriculture being deplorable, but. nothing that Germany had done had contravened the spirit or letter of any treaty or understanding with Great Britain. Dumping was only part of the greater problem of the control and supply of wheat getting into fewer hands. This year there had been a sudden price slump, owing to large holders being forced to unload suddenly. There were huge combines of wheat buyers in Britain as well as sellers.. Overseas buying was practically limited to three large combines, plus a co-operative wholesale society.

debate.para: If private enterprise has limited the sales of Australian wheat in Great Britain, these large combines must react to the detriment of the Australian farmer. If the Australian wheat producer desires to protect his interests, his only hope is in the adoption of the pooling system which I am advocating and which I trust this Government will assist in establishing.

talk.start.para: - Since the honorable senator favours an. organization to act as policeman over private enterprise in the disposal of the Australian wheat crop, does he not think that it would be an advantage to have some organization to police it? Would not the wheat grower derive greater advantage by having two activities in the field ?

- I have already intimated that I do not think the two activities in the field are of benefit to the growers. Conditions might arise when a competitor with a pooling system might be able to take advantage of exceptional circumstances prevailing in the wheat market in a way that the pool could not.- Instances have occurred where private buyers have been able to benefit by temporary wheat shortages to a greater extent than a pooling organization possibly could. All that the wheat farmers are asking for, and all any producer is entitled to, is a fair market value for the commodity he produces, and which would be available to him under a properlycontrolled pooling system. A Commonwealth pooling system, or a series of State pools with a central selling organization, would not only be beneficial to the wheat-growing industry, but of great advantage to the country generally.
- If all wheat were pooled, on what basis would the market value of wheat bo ascertained?

- As the honorable senator is aware, tremendous speculation ' takes place in connexion with wheat sales. Shipments placed on board vessels at Australian ports are in some instances sold and their destination changed several times while they are still on the water. As a result of these resales and speculation generally the margin between the price received by the producer and that paid by the consumer is often increased, and it is to reduce that margin that the Labour party is endeavouring to evolve a co-operative marketing system under the control of the growers.

debate.para: The wool-growers are in a similar position. I venture to say that the recent slump in wool values, which to a great extent was due to speculation, has awakened the wool-producers of this country. They made a mistake a few years ago when they , rejected a scheme for a continuation of a wool-pooling system, and an agitation for a reintroduction of that system will probably be revived in the near future. The arguments which I have adduced in favour of the wheat-pooling system could also be used with equal force in connexion with our wool production.

I notice from a> paragraph in the Governor-General's Speech, that the Government intend to honour the promise made by the previous administration in the matter of granting financial assistance to South Australia. The urgency of this matter is, I am sure, well known to honorable senators. The case was fully presented to Parliament in the report furnished by the South Australia Disabilities Commission, which conducted a full and complete inquiry on behalf of the late Government. I under stand that the present administration intends to be more generous, and will grant the full amount recommended by the commission without imposing any unnecessary obligations upon the State Government.. If that is so, I feel sure that the people of South Australia will be grateful to the present Government for the financial assistance which they will shortly receive.

It is not my intention to reiterate the pleas I made on behalf of the viticultural industry some months ago except to say that what I said on that occasion has proved by subsequent events to be true. South Australia is the principal wineproducing State in the Commonwealth; of the 18,000,000 gallons of wine beverage or spirit produced in the Commonwealth, no less than 14,000,000 gallons are produced in South Australia. Unless the industry can be assisted in successfully marketing its product over a period of years, or until the Wine Export Control Board can, -by improved marketing methods and advertising, increase sales abroad, the industry in South Australia will be in a parlous condition. The recoil will be upon a section of the industry least able to bear it. More particularly will it adversely affect returned soldier settlers, who were virtually compelled by the State government of the day to engage in the wine industry. Because conditions were then propitious, the market favorable and prices high, that government prepared and planted large areas with wine grapes, and on those areas it repatriated returned soldiers. The result was a large increase in the wine production of Australia. The first of the new areas came substantially into production in 1922, the output being 8,542,573 gallons. In 1923 that had increased to 11,427,793 gallons, and in 1924 to 14,663,S81 gallons. In 1925 the output was 13,299,290 gallons; in 1926, 16,224,741 gallons; in 1927, 20,456,341 gallons; in 1928, 17,302,611; while for 1929 the estimated production of Australia is 18,399,968 gallons. The greater bulk of that increase represents the product of areas which were planted for the repatriation of returned soldiers, and the increase has caused the present difficulty. It has brought about a surplus beyond the capacity of " the Australian market to absorb, and compels us to establish markets elsewhere, a task at present beset with difficulty.

talk.start.para: - Why not sell the wine cheaper in Australia, and so increase the home market ?

- That suggestion is worthy of consideration, but it is not the fault of the growers that wine is not retailed more cheaply in Australia. Speaking from memory, the grower receives about £7 10s. a ton for his grapes, and after they are processed, the excise duties .paid and the various marketing channels traversed, the consumer pays at the rate of something like £114 per ton on the resultant beverage. Those figures were supplied to me by Colonel Francis, who is vitally interested in the problem in South Australia, and who assures me that they are correct. The task is chiefly one calling for State action. The Federal Government derives a large amount of revenue from the brandy production branch, of the industry, and I think that out of that revenue it would be justified in granting assistance to the wine beverage side. That could be done by slightly increasing the bounty and by a continuation of drawbacks and control for a period of years. I would not advocate that procedure were I not convinced that eventually we shall find a market for our surplus overseas, also in Australia, by reason of our increased population. It would be a tragedy if in ten years time we found that we had a" market for 20,000,000 gallons of wine, and we were unable to supply it because we had put the grubbing axe into large holdings on account of the present unfavorable position. That would be a tragedy not only to the settler, but to the government of South Australia, which has sunk large sums of money in the industry, draining, channelling, providing pumping plants, and otherwise assisting to place areas under cultivation. I trust that the Federal Labour Government will adopt a more sympathetic attitude towards the wine industry than did its predecessor, which reduced the bounty by 9d. a gallon two years ago, and so precipitated the present crisis. I am confident that if the policy that I have outlined is followed the industry will eventually stand firmly on its feet. It is an industry that brings to Australia a considerable volume of outside wealth, and provides in this country employment for a large number of people. It is also responsible for bringing under intense production areas of land which, comparatively speaking, would be poor for cereal growing, grazing, and many other forms of primary production.

debate.para: In conclusion, I express my confidence that this Government will grapple with the tasks which confront it in that satisfactory manner with which other Labour governments in the Commonwealth have surmounted obstacles. It is my belief that this Government will justify the confidence reposed in it by the large majority of the electors of Australia ; that, as the years go by, it will establish a record, which will eclipse that of its predecessor in the matter of mere length of tenure of office and, what is more important, that it will leave behind such a record of good work that it will be said of it with pride, " Something attempted, something done."

Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE (Western Australia [4.59]. - I desire, first of all, to congratulate Senator Daly and Senator Barnes, the former on having become the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and the latter upon his accession to office in the Ministry. I am sure that Senator Daly must have been rendered almost breathless by the speed with which he has shifted from one position to another in this chamber. He had scarcely become comfortable in his' seat as Leader of the Opposition when he found himself Leader of the Government in the Senate I assure Senator Daly and his colleagues that honorable senators on this side will do everything to assist the conduct of business in the Senate, and that Ave shall not unnecessarily interfere with its progress.

Before dealing with matters arising out of the Governor-General's Speech, I shall address myself to one or two remarks emanating from the mover and seconder of the Address-in-Reply, beginning with those made by Senator O'Halloran. The honorable senator's remarks remind me of a bell wether, a very convenient animal: usually an old and tractable sheep whose services are requisitioned to lead his fellow sheep into the muster yard. For a long time the farmers of Australia have been particularly suspicious of the Labour party. Now we find that party professing to be their greatest friend. We find gentlemen like Senator O'Halloran going about the country making long, plausible speeches about wheat pools, and talking learnedly to farmers as fellow farmers, all with the hope that those farmers will be inveigled into the yard of the Labour party. But let it be noted that the farmers are not expected to read Senator Dooley's speech, in which he advocates that all imported goods should be shut out of Australia. According to him we are to have a tariff that will definitely prevent importation of goods into this country. Naturally if Senator O'Halloran were to make such a pronouncement to his new-found friends, they would at once declare, " That is going to put up the price of things that we have to buy, and it will i u jure us when we are in competition with the markets of the world. How are we to sell our products if all imports are to be shut out of Australia, and we are to be restricted to purchasing all our requirements in this market?" So Senator O'Halloran keeps tactfully quiet on that phase of the subject, and confines his attention to the wine industry and wheat pools. But what would be the position of our wine industry if other countries were to adopt the suggestions of Senator Dooley and apply them to our wines. Incidentally, while not proceeding exactly along those lines, the Labour Government in Great Britain does propose to destroy the preference on Australian wines, and, when that is done, Senator O'Halloran will have very carefully to eschew any references to the blessings of Labour governments in connexion with our wine industry. Such references might cause some of his new-found friends to remember that that Labour Government in Great Britain intends to take a step prejudicial to the industry, one that will wipe away a preference which was established by a Conservative government.

To-day we have a rather extraordinary occurrence in connexion with federal governments, one which I think is a record. We are about to be presented with a budget from the new Labour Treasurer, who tells us that the previous budget has had to be revised. Then we have Senator

O'Halloran, who, accidently, happens to be a South Australian representative, announcing in anticipation of the new budget that the Labour Government intends to pay the full amount of the grant to South Australia. That, I assume, is merely electioneering tactics, to divert to Senator O'Halloran glory that is really due to an opposing party. While Senator O'Halloran was talking so learnedly about wheat pools, I looked through the Governor-General's speech to see if it announced the establishment of a compulsory wheat pool, but found no mention of one. Apparently Senator O'Halloran's talk about such a pool is nothing but political birdlime to mislead those people in the wayback, often referred to as hayseeds, who read Mansard, into the belief that this Government intends to do "something for them. The honorable senator's remarks reminded me of a leaflet which was, during the recent election, circulated in the Calare constituency under the name of Mr. Gibbons. It promised the farmers that if a Labour Government were returned to power they would get 6s. 6d. a bushel for their wheat and it probably won the Calare seat for Labour. At any rate Senator O'Halloran's talk about a compulsory wheat pool, no mention of which is made in the Governor-General's speech, is merely political birdlime.

Many strange promises were made during the election. Passing through South Australia the other day I encountered a friend who had been there' during the general election. I am sorry Senator O'Halloran is leaving the Chamber because this is a matter that intimately concerns him. My friend told me that he had listened to a speech by one of the supporters of the Labour party in South Australia in which r terrible picture of the devastation caused by the drought in the north of the State and in Eyre's Peninsula was drawn. I pricked up my ears when my friend told me that this gentleman was speaking very well on agricultural questions, because I remembered Senator O'Halloran making very long, speeches in this Chamber on agricultural questions, and I said to myself. " This must be my friend, O'Halloran". My other friend went on to tell me that this gentleman said that the poor unfortunate farmers who had been starved out on Eyre's Peninsula, were victims of Liberal administration, and that if Labour had been in office they would never have been permitted to go out into the dry areas ; that only quite recently the Commonwealth Government, through its agents the Development and Migration Commission, had been instrumental in having an area of land opened up in the north-west mallee district in Victoria, and was putting people on land where he knew quite well they would starve, because they could not possibly live on it. Now I happened to know that the proposal that had been made in regard to the north-west portion of the mallee in Victoria had been put forward, not by a Liberal or Nationalist Government, but by the Hogan Labour Government of Victoria. It was a proposal to develop what is known as the Nowingi area, and in this regard, let me quote from the second annual report of the Development and Migration Commission. The Victorian Government referred to in the report was, as I have already said, the Hogan Labour Government. On page 35 will be found the following: -

quote.para: Notoingi Railway. - Early in 1928, the Victorian Government submitted a proposal for the construction of a railway and roads in the North-Western Mallee district. The proposal involved the development and settlement of a strip of country westwards from Nowingi and immediately south of the settlement on the existingRedclilfs-Merringur railway.
The submission contemplated the following expenditure: -

debate.para: After preliminary examination of this proposal, the Commission felt that it was a marginal proposition, and decided, with the concurrence of the State authorities, to conduct a detailed economic survey of the area, with a view to estimating the total costs of development and the results which might be expected to accrue therefrom, both to the settlers and to the community as a whole.

Although the submission was for the construction of 35 miles of railway, and the associated feeder roads, it was made clear that the Victorian Government contemplated the development of the whole area of country between Nowingi and the South Australian border. This would involve the construction of 50 miles of railway, and the execution of other necessary public works, including proposed reticulation by means of waterchannels involving an expenditure of approximately £500,000.
The Commission's examination, therefore, related to the estimated costs and results of the development of the area which would be served by a 56-mile railway.

In a report submitted to the Government in November, 1928, the Commission set out particularsof its inquiries, and discussed the prospects of profitable settlement. Briefly, the principal facts adduced and the conclusions reached were the following: -

item.para: 1 ) The total capital outlay, both public and private, which would be involved would be at least £2,500,000.
The total annual turnover for a considerable period subsequent to the period of development would be approximately £410,000, which was regarded as small in relation to the capital outlay.

Senator O'Halloran - because apparently he was the gentleman who made use of this matter during the election to appeal to farmers in the dry areas of South Australia to vote against the Bruce-Page Government, on the ground that it was responsible for this kind of thing - has thus failed in his claim that the Nowingi scheme was fathered by a Nationalist Government in the State of Victoria.

Senator Dooley said that the present Government would emulate -the Fisher Government. If the present Government seeks to emulate the Fisher Government it is going about it in a very curious way. I was a member of that government. I was Mr. Fisher's Minister for Defence, and I well remember moving the introduction of the bill for the inauguration of universal and compulsory military service. The measure was carried unanimously in both Houses, and having carried it, the Labour party went into the country and boasted about it. We said, "What did the Liberals do? They merely carried compulsory training, for boys, whereas we, the real patriots, have extended it to the men. We are going to train every adult in this country up to the age of twenty-one." We said that every person, physically fit and living in a district where he could conveniently be trained, must be trained to enable him to take part in the defence of his country. We boasted about all this. We said that our method was better than that which the Liberals put forward. If the present Government proposes to emulate the Fisher Government by abolishing compulsory military training, I tremble to think of the likely fate of the whole temple of Labour, which was raised in the years from 1910 to 1913. I suggest that Senator Dooley reflects before he again compares this Government with the Fisher Government.

The recent election resulted in the defeat of the Bruce-Page Government. There was no election for members of the Senate, so that honorable senators are still in the position of having the endorsement of the electors. A peculiar position has arisen in this Parliament, for in one chamber there is a preponderance of Labour members, whereas in the other Nationalist and Country party members predominate. I take this opportunity of saying that the Opposition in the Senate will not deal in any partisan spirit with the legislation that comes before it. Each measure will be judged from two points of view - first, whether the Government has authority for its introduction, and secondly, its effect on the country. We on this side recognize "that the Government has received a mandate from the people in connexion with industrial matters. The electors undoubtedly desire that the present dual system shall continue. We shall recognize the mandate they have given the Government. Any legislation introduced to amend the arbitration system in order that it may work more smoothly; any attempt to create a better spirit between employers and employees; any effort to extend the principle of conciliation, will receive our hearty support. The Government need expect no opposition to such legislation, for we recognize that it is entitled to legislate in respect of industrial matters. The election was largely fought upon that issue, and the people gave their verdict. But on other questions the Government will have to establish, to the satisfaction of the country, its right to change the existing legislation before the Opposition will support any measure introduced for that purpose.

I desire to draw attention to the change in the representation of the Government in the Senate. For many years various governments have recognized the importance of the Senate in this respect, although it is true that in the early years of federation this chamber did not receive that recognition in ministerial appointments that was its due. From 1901 to 1910, the Barton, the first Deakin, the Watson, the Reid-McLean, the second Deakin, the first Fisher, and the third Deakin Ministries were represented in the Senate by one minister with a portfolio and the Vice-President of the Executive Council. From 1910 to 1916, during the administration of the second Fisher, the Cook, the third Fisher and the first Hughes Governments, the Senate, in addition to having a minister with a portfolio and the Vice-President of the Executive Council, had also an honorary minis- ter. Between 1916 and 1926, a period which embraced the second Hughes ministry, the two Nationalist war governments, as well as the Bruce-Page Government, the Senate had two ministers with portfolios and one honorary minister. In June, 1926, the Bruce-Page Government increased the number of ministers in the Senate to four - one minister with a portfolio, the Vice-President of the Executive Council, and two honorary ministers. It will therefore be seen that from the inception of federation the Senate has had either two ministers with full ministerial rank, or one minister and the Vice-President of' the Executive Council. It has remained for this Government to deprive the Senate of any minister with a portfolio. The Senate is now on a lower plane as regards ministerial appointments than it has ever been since the inception of federation. I protest against such treatment of the Senate, particularly as it is quite unnecessary. The Government's failure to recognize the position of the Senate in the Constitution cannot be excused on the ground that its numbers in this chamber are small. During the regime of the first Deakin Government the number of its supporters in the Senate was small, but that Government did not disregard the Senate's claims to recognition in the matter of ministerial appointments. I do not know whether we can take any effective means of emphasizing our protest in. this matter, but I feel that the Government's action warrants more than passing criticism.

The Government won the election largely because of the promises it made to the electors. One of those promises had relation to the removal of unemployment. Labour party candidates, especially when addressing electors in industrial centres, made it appear that in their opinion the Bruce-Page Government was largely responsible for the unemployment then existing. To-day the Labour party is being called upon to deliver the goods, lt is no longer in Opposition, incapable of doing more than criticize. But we look in vain to the Governor-General's Speech for any ray of hope for the unemployed. It is true that the Speech contains a paragraph that it is not proposed to appoint a Director of Economic Research. That will result in a very doubtful saving of about £2,000 per annum. Is that grain of sand to be offered to the unemployed? Theunemployed are told to " wait and see." The miseries of the unemployed men and their families were exploited by Labour candidates in order to secure the support of electors for themselves and to create hostility to Nationalist candidates. Those electors will find nothing in the Governor-General's Speech to assuage their suffering.
In connexion with the trouble in the coal-mining industry, the Government also made definite promises. I have here an extract from the Sydney Morning Herald of Monday, the 7th October, 1929-

talk.start.para: - He certainly anticipated more co-operation from others than ho has received.

Until Mr. McGrath told him he was not aware that the people would be behind this administrative act. On what ground did the Government abolish compulsory training? Several reasons have been advanced, but not one of them is conclusive. In the first place it was reported that the Treasurer (Mr. Theodore), having examined the finances, declared that the abolition of compulsory training would lead to substantial savings in 'expenditure. On that point I remind the Senate that the respective platforms of the several parties were placed before the people at the general election in November last, and on that occasion the electors endorsed the platforms of the Nationalist and Country parties. - It was mentioned in the policy speech of the present Prime Minister.

He added that the plans for training volunteers prepared by the authorities aimed at brighter and more attractive conditions of training and a smarter uniform. This apparently is what the Labour party has been waiting for all these years I According to Senators Dooley and Dunn, Labour has been in the wilderness for fourteen years, and now, having reached office again, it has produced something! This, we are informed, is Labour's efficient defence policy! The report states that the rates of pay will be the same as under the compulsory system, and then quotes Brigadier-General Dodds as saying -

The question of a betterfitting uniform has been under consideration for some time, and an attractive tunic has been evolved. Khaki will be retained. The tunic is cut on neater lines than previously, without pockets in the shirt, a half belt in place of a full belt, and upstanding collar and sleeves without cuffs. debate.para: Apparently the Government has ample funds at its disposal, since it has, according to Senator O'Halloran, agreed to pay a grant of £500,000 to South Australia - but it is estimated that the new uniform would not cost 50 per cent. more than that usually issued to trainees. It is also proposed that trainees should be issued with web equipment for purposes of training.

I direct particular attention to the latter part of the statement, in view of the Government's declaration that compulsory military training has been suspended for reasons of economy. What does all this change amount to? Apparently , instead of a low-cut collar, volunteer trainees are to be supplied with uniforms with stiff upright collars and coloured pipings, and the new uniform is not to cost 50 per cent. more than that previously issued ! How all this must stir up the anti-military spirit of our friend Senator Rae! We can imagine how enthusiastically he will endorse this new defence policy of the Labour Government! At last we are to have an effective defence policy for Australia - a policy that conforms to Labour's ideals! On manyoccasions we have heard a number of honorable senators now supporting the Government denouncing the evils of militarism, and all the pomp and circumstance that attach to it. Boiled down, it would appear that the difference between militarism and Labour's idea of effective defence is the difference between an upright collar with coloured pipings and a collar that is not upright; between a full shirt with pockets and a shirt with none! WhenI was listening to Senator - Dunn, I had no idea that the only difference between the militarism as we have known it in the past, and an effective defence scheme as evolved by the Labour Government, is a difference in the cut of the military coat. I never thought that if the trainee was clothed in a loose-fitting tunic, he was a representative of militarism, but that if he were wearing a coat with a waist like a tailor's model, he conformed to Labour's latest idea of an effective defence unit.

But turning for a moment from the satirical aspect, of Labour's defence policy, I desire, in serious mood, to direct the attention of the Senate to what is happening in other countries, and to indicate the views of governments of other countries, far more powerful than we are, concerning disarmament. I now come to the second destructive act of this Government - the suspension of migration. Here again the Government acted precipitately. The first announcement, telegraphed from Canberra to the press, over the name of the Prime Minister, was to the effect that the Government had suspended assisted migration. That announcement was, of course, intended for consumption by those who during the election campaign had been gulled by certain stories, such as we have heard this afternoon, concerning the alleged relationship between migration and unemployment. But when it was pointed out to the Prime Minister that this assisted migration scheme did not stand alone - that it was linked up with a development scheme and a loan of £34,000,000 at a very low rate of interest to assist in the development of the States - the Government changed its ground. We were then told that it had not suspended assisted immigration, but had despatched a communication to the British Government setting out its views on the subject, and that when it received a reply the whole matter would be taken into consideration. What are the facts in regard to migration? For the first nine months of 1928 the arrivals and departures of British migrants were as follows : - Arrivals, 58,875 ; departures, 44,240; or an excess of 14,635 arrivals over departures. We then come to the bad days of unemployment, and we find there is an automatic check. For the first nine months of 1929, the arrivals were 48,775, and the departures 45,378, or an excess of arrivals over departures of only 3,397. If this vast continent, with a population of over 6,250,000, is faced with unemployment solely because of an additional 3,397 people in the Commonwealth, there must surely be something wrong. Are we to advertise it to the world that because the arrivals exceeded the departures by 3,000 odd during the first nine months of the present year, we have, according to. the stories of honorable senators opposite, an army of 200,000 unemployed? We are then told that the Government and its supporters do not object to our own kith and kin coming to Australia, but are strongly opposed to foreigners coming into this country' and taking the food out of the mouths of fellow-Australians.

Yet this Government has said to Great Britain, through its Prime Minister, "We have received some 10,000 of your unemployed. They are swamping us. It is true that our population increased by excess of arrivals over departures last year by only 3,000, but we cannot employ them all.

Our unemployment problem is so acute that although every domestic servant that we brought to Australia in the last twelve months was given employment as soon as she landed, and did not put anybody out of work, and although the organizations concerned have letters from these boys, that we brought to Australia, saying they are being well trained and well brought up, with a future in front of them, we- do not want any more of your domestic servants or boys in future". Most of the domestics were unemployed girls from the middle districts of Lancashire. Their migration to Australia opened to them the' possibility of a future instead of their being allowed to suffer the pangs of hunger and even starvation, while we needed their services in Australia. Yet this Government says %o them " Stay away. There is work for you here but if you dome you might displace some hardy waterside worker in Sydney, or possibly some shearer in Queensland." The Government practically says to Great Britain " We ask you to keep your domestics but, whilst we cannot take those domestic servants or your boys and give them a home, in Australia, and a chance to become good citizens of this country, we urge you, for heavens sake to take our wheat, our wool, our wine, butter and dried fruits, and continue the preference you are giving on our wine and our dried fruits. Also, for heaven's sake, do notrefuse to lend us money* although we do not want your men." I think one might well paraphrase an old- doggerel and declare, " We don't want your girls, we don't want your boys; but, by jingo, we do want your money, and we want it badly. too." In effect, this Government says " We do not want your men because, whilst it may relieve your unemployment, it will, to some little extent, aggravate our unemployment problem. But we do want your money to help us to find work for our unemployed."

Now I come to the third act of destruction, the suspension of licences to waterside workers. That is another gesture 10 the communistic comrades outside. The Government says in effect to them, " We are going to let you again enjoy yourselves in the good old way, and as soon, as it is safe we shall deal another deadly blow at this Transport Workers Act. We " will get rid of it altogether." And then, when- Senator O'Halloran's farmer friend sends his wheat to be shipped, probably next year, the other branch of the honorable senator's family, having done away with the Transport Workers Act, a nice little waterside workers' strike will be precipitated. Senator O'Halloran will promptly go into recess until the strike is over, and Senator Dooley will take his place in the interim, and ' talk about economic freedom, the brotherhood of man, and all that kind of thing. But Senator O'Halloran will resume business soon as the strike is over, and will talk once more to the farmers about the blessings of a compulsory wheat pool. Australia has had a few months of peace in the waterside industry, but now, by this act of destruction, we have an attempt to reintroduce industrial warfare on the waterfront.

I have passed under review the three destructive acts of this new Labour Government. I come now to its one constructive act: the appointment of the Hibble tribunal. The recent election was won on a cry of wage reduction, and the first constructive act of the Government brings about a proposal for a reduction of wages. As soon as that finding is made by - the chairman of the tribunal appointed by the Prime Minister to investigate the trouble in the coal-mining industry it is denounced - and denounced by the Prime Minister himself, followed by his Treasurer.

And what do our friends opposite intend to do about Johu Brown? They had a glorious time during the election in connexion with John Brown. From every platform they asserted that, by failing to prosecute John Brown, the Nationalist Government had thwarted the ends of justice. I can visualize Senator Dunn lifting the roof by his passionate vociferations regarding the setting aside of that prosecution. Honorable senators opposite declared that John Brown had caused a lockout, and that the course of the Government was clear. If it was a lockout then, it is still a lockout. This Government has been in -power for a month. What has it done with John Brown? Why has it not prosecuted him?
