speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.I wish now to say a few words with regard to the Government's proposal to tamper with the £34,000,000 migration agreement. I have already dealt with the matter in regard to assisted migration. The agreement provides for the advancing of money for developmental purposes to the various States of the Commonwealth. As a matter of fact, the full £34,000,000 is available for works of a developmental character approved by the Commonwealth and British Governments at 1-J per cent, interest for the first five years and one-third of the effective rate of interest for a further five years. The terms of the agreement are of tremendous advantage to the States, who for the ten years during which most developmental works are un reproductive will pay a very cheap rate of interest for the money advanced to them. It is very unlikely, however, if this agreement is tampered with, that the British Government will be at all solicitous to extend the operation of that part of the agreement. It has financial difficulties of its own, and it was a very generous act on its part to agree to share the interest burden on our developmental works. I am, therefore, astonished that at a time like this, when money is required .for developmental work, in order to provide employment, a government which professes to be anxious about providing employment should be proposing to seek an alteration in the agreement that furnishes the States with money for that purpose.

There is another feature of this agree- ment to which I wish to draw particular attention. It is an undoubted fact that, in the past, money has been squandered on public works that have not been fully investigated before being approved. Knowing this, the British and Commonwealth Governments made a stipulation that before the developmental works proposed to be undertaken under the migration agreement could be approved they had to be inquired into by a competent body to ascertain if they were economically sound. For that reason the Development and Migration Commission was appointed, chiefly because of the individual fitness of its members and also because as a composite body it could bring various types of minds to bear on the different questions likely to come before it for review. At first the various States looked upon this body with a rather jealous eye; they were rather suspicious of it, but gradually the commission, by working in with the States, lias gained the confidence of every State Government, and, what is equally important, that of the State departments. The latter have come to realize that it is a body whose purpose it is to assist thom, and not .to interfere with them in their work. It is no exaggeration to say that to-day the Development and Migration Commission has earned the full confidence and also the full cooperation of every State Government and State department. I therefore cannot understand why there should lie any proposal to interfere with it. I am led to believe that the proposal of the Government is to have the work done by some Commonwealth department. The Development and Migration Commission has been accepted by the States and State departments, because they have gradually come to realize that it is not in the true sense a Commonwealth Government department, but that it is a semi-independent body. If these State departments are now to subordinate themselves and their work' to the control of a Commonwealth Government department I predict that very serious difficulty and friction will soon arise. The States of Tasmania and Western Australia have received tremendous assistance from the Development and Migration Commission. When application was first made to the Bruce-Page Government for a continuance of the Tasmanian grant that Government thought it would be a good thing for the two administrations concerned to investigate the cause of Tasmania's financial positi'on. It suggested that the Development and Migration Commission should be asked to make an investigation on behalf of both governments, and report as to means by which the State might be able to carry on without so much assistance from the Commonwealth. That inquiry was made with full co-operation between the Commonwealth Government and the State Government, and as a result various recommendations were made for the reorganization of the Agricultural Department of Tasmania, and for the establishment of agricultural bureaux and forestry bureaux. Various measures were suggested for promoting co-operative effort in agriculture. All these recommendations have been put into effect by the Tasmanian Parliament, and it is generally agreed that the work done in that respect, has been of great .assistance to Tasmania, particularly in putting her on a much sounder financial footing.

Western Australia having very extensive areas of Crown lands available for settlement has provided great opportunities for development, and consequently has received a largo amount of assistance under the migration agreement. The Development and Migration Commission, in this ' connexion, has gained the entire confidence of all parties in that State. When the intention of the Federal Labour Government was announced, Mr. Collier, the Labour Premier of Western Australia, referring to the proposed suspension of the clause of the migration agreement relating to assisted migration and the future of the Development and Migration Commission, said - " Without expressing any opinion on the broad matter of policy as to whether the Development and Migration Commission should he abolished or retained, I should like to say that its work in Western Australia has been very valuable and of great assistance to the State. Every proposal submitted to the commission by us has been examined most thoroughly, and for the past twelve months it has been making a careful study of the land settlement project known as the 3,000 farms scheme, with which is associated the construction of many hundreds of miles of roads and. railways and some important water supply works. If approved under the Migration Agreement, this big project can be carried out within five years, but without the assistance provided for under the agreement, the State would probably be unable to complete it within twenty years. Of course I cannot speak for the other States, but, so far as Western Australia is concerned, we have been greatly assisted through the investigations of the commission in our task of developing the State.

That was reported in the West Australian of the 8th November, 1929. On the 15th November, 1929, Sir James Mitchell, Leader of the Opposition in the Western Australian Parliament, and Leader of the Nationalist party in the State, published an article in the West Australian dealing with migration and unemployment, in the course of which he said -

quote.para: The Commonwealth Prime Minister's request to the British Government for a temporary suspension of assisted migration during the present period of unemployment and trade depression, whatever its effects may be, should achieve good by focusing the attention of the people on some of the hard, and disagreeable yet inexorable facts of our economic life that can no longer be ignored. It cannot be the desire of the Federal Government that the population of Australia should not be increased. Mr. Scullin's. difficulty is the shortage of work offering for our own people, and his idea obviously is that the problem of unemployment cannot be solved except by stopping immigration. To my mind that is quite an erroneous view, but while Mr. Scullin's Government and other Governments in Australia hold it, there ought not to be any more migration to this country. We must not only banish unemployment, but also remove the fear of unemployment.

At the same time it will be a very serious matter for this State if we are not to get the advantage of the cheap money under the migration agreement. It will be remembered that under the agreement we were to pay one per cent. On the money advanced for the first five years, and then one-third of the actual interest rate for the next five years, after which we were to assume full responsibility for the whole of the interest. So far we have received £4,489,000 under the arrangement, which has already saved us £600,000 in interest, while the total saving on that sum will be £1,346,936. This is an enormous advantage for a State that must have money for development work. If Britain is willing help this State to the extent of £10,000,000, as arranged, the saving in interest will be no less than £3,875,000.In other words, Britain has offered to assist the development of the State by advancing £10,000,000, and the interest concession represents a gift to the State of £3,875.000 compared with the interest liability on on equivalent amount borrowed in the ordinary way. People can judge for themselves what it will mean to the State if we lose that advantage. It will mean so much money less to provide employment under this heading, for if we borrowed an equal amount at ordinary interest rates the difference between the respective rates would necessarily have to be deducted from the money available to provide work.

speech.para: The same story can be told of all the States, but I want to give an instance of how the Development and Migration Commission has saved Queensland from a wasteful expenditure, which would have been a very serious burden to the State. The Queensland Labour Government submitted to the Queensland Parliament what is known as the Dawson Valley irrigation scheme. That scheme was proposed in all sincerity by an enthusiastic engineer, who obviously did not have full knowledge as regards soil and various other factors, which are essential to make an irrigation scheme a success. There was no investigation as to the products likely to be produced on the country to be irrigated, nor of the prospects of finding a profitable market for whatever was produced. Yet the Queensland Government was about to commit the State to this scheme. In order, however, to get the advantage of the cheap money under the migration agreement it made application to the Commonwealth Government to have the scheme brought under that agreement. That necessitated an investigation by the Development and Migration Commission, and when that investigation was made it was ascertained, first of all, that the soil and dairy experts of the Queensland agricultural departments had never been asked for a report as to the suitability of the country proposed to be irrigated, or as to the possibility of carrying on dairying in the area.

talk.start.para: - Is that not a reflection on the State government?

- Possibly it is, but I am merely attempting to show how the Development and Migration Commission has prevented wasteful expenditure in Australia. If it had not been for the fact that under the terms of the migration agreement it was necessary to have an investigation by some competent body, the Dawson Valley Irrigation scheme would have been saddled on the taxpayers of Queensland to-day. After full investigation the commission reported adversely on the scheme and said that before the State should be committed to it experiments on a small scale should be carried on in various parts of the area in order to determine whether it would be possible to carry on similar operations on a big scale. It is possible that these experiments are now being conducted in Queensland to-day.

speech.para: That is an instance of the way in which The Development and Migration Commission prevented the people of Queensland from incurring a liability of £4,000,000. If the same procedure had been adopted in regard to soldier settlement how many millions of pounds would have been saved ro the various States? It is all very well to say that the States can look after these matters, but we know that millions of pounds have been squandered in soldier settlement because various schemes were not investigated before the State governments embarked on them. The body set up by the Bruce-Page Government to investigate in an impartial way altogether free from politics these proposals for expenditure and to look particularly into their soundness, has done good work. I have given two instances to-day in which it has saved Queensland and Victoria from an expenditure of huge sums of money. It would be a disaster to the Commonwealth to abolish a body, which is just the very thing we need in Australia to conduct investigations and prevent th6 reckless expenditure of money Money is going to be very hard to get in the future. We know that we should have been careful in the past. There is a double reason for being careful in the future. Yet here we have a government talking about unemployment and about providing employment by means of developmental works, proposing to get rid of the one body that has done effective work in Australia in the investigation of schemes on which public money was proposed to be spent. [Extension of time granted.']

talk.start.para: - Did the commission report on the Clarence Valley scheme?

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.I think not, but it reported on the Lachlan River scheme. I point out that the States have gradually acquired the habit of placing proposed schemes before the commission before giving approval to them. In the two cases I have mentioned approval was given to the schemes before their submission to the commission, but in a number of other cases the States have first referred the matters to the commission for investigation, and when that body has reported adversely the schemes have not been proceeded with.

talk.start.para: - Did the commission report on the ability of the schemes to absorb further labour?

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.Every scheme recommended by the commission is one calculated to increase the absorptive powers of the Commonwealth. The Lachlan River scheme, for instance, concerns a tract of 300,000 acres of land from which the production can be increased immensely.

talk.start.para: - How many additional men will that scheme absorb?

- I suggest that Senator Daly, who is now administering the department, should read the report of the commission. He will then see that it deals with the matter he has raised. Every scheme referred to the commission has been dealt with from the point of view of its increasing the absorptive powers of the Commonwealth.
- The Development and Migration Commission has admitted otherwise.
- Before the Development and Migration Commission is abolished by the Government I hope that the matters to which I have referred will be seriously considered by them.

speech.para: Dealing with the Development and Migration Commission the Governor-General's Speech stated -

quote.para: My Ministers propose to co-ordinate the functions of the Development and Migration Commission which was established in accordance with the Development and Migration Act of 1.926, with those of the Commonwealth Council of Scientific and Industrial Research; and this work will be brought under the direct control of the Department of the Prime Minister.

speech.para: As the work of the Commission is already under the direct control of the Department of the Prime Ministerno change is contemplated. What is meant by that paragraph? The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research is an entirely different body from the Development and Migration Commission and has altogether different functions. How can there he co-ordination between a body dealing with developmental matters and one whose business it is to make scientific investigations? The members of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research may know nothing of developmental matters; indeed, they were appointed because of their knowledge, not of such matters, hut of science and the application of science. The members of the Development and Migration Commission, on the other hand, were chosen not because they knew a great deal about science, but because they had been trained to judge the economic value of developmental schemes. Whoever is responsible for the proposal outlined in that paragraph does not understand the different functions of the two bodies. The Government's proposal is almost equivalent to suggesting that the work of the Commissioner of Railways in Victoria should be co-ordinated with that of the University of Melbourne. That would mean that instead of Mr. Clapp controlling the Victorian railways, the University of Melbourne would control them. The proposal of the Government will either destroy the usefulness of the Development and Migration Commission or load the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research with duties for which it is entirely unfitted. No persons in the community would be more ready to admit their inability to undertake the work of the Development and Migration Commission than would the members of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research.

talk.start.para: - Members of the two bodies meet together frequently, and did so meet while the right honorable gentleman was in office.

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.The Department of Markets deals with marketing of our produce; the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research deals with research problems affecting production ; the Development and Migra tion Commission deals with the extension of fruit production, dairying, and other similar matters. In some cases the matters dealt with by these bodies are closely related; and, in order to prevent overlapping, their members meet with the Minister once a month in order to corelate their work in such a way that overlapping is prevented. That is not coordination in the sense that one body carries out the functions of another. It is merely an endeavour to avoid the danger of one department doing the work of another.

talk.start.para: - There is no intention to allow one department to undertake the functions of another.

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.Another destructive act of the Government since it assumed office was the suspension of licences for waterside workers. This is another instance of the Government's interference with a deliberate legislative act of this Parliament without the authority of Parliament. What is the object of suspending these licences, seeing that, for the first time since 1917, we have had a period of peace on the waterfront? The Government which talks of industrial peace and of solving the problem of unemployment has dealt a blow at the one measure which has brought industrial peace on the waterfront.

talk.start.para: - That piece of legislation has caused injustice on the waterfront.

speech.para: Senator Sir GEORGE PEARCE.It is evident that the hand of the Government has been forced by the extreme element in its ranks. The result will probably be that, instead of the peace which has reigned on the waterfront during recent months, there will be a repetition of the scenes of the past, when the industries of this country were held up. Should trouble again develop, what would the Government do? We should probably find it arranging futile conferences, and granting all sorts of concessions to those who caused the trouble. The restoration of peace would be at the expense of the community.

The Government won many votes because of its declared intention not to impose the amusement tax proposed by the late Government. The American moving picture interests in this country, by the expenditure of much money and the circulation of propaganda, did a great deal to assist the Labour party to win the election. The Government has announced that it will not proceed with the taxation proposals of the Bruce-Page Government in respect of amusements; but it proposes to tax the industries of this country by imposing increased taxation through the Post Office. The money which the late Government expected to derive from the taxation of amusement companies will now be derived from an additional tax on newspapers, periodicals, telephones and telegrams. Instead of the American moving picture interests assisting to balance the ledger, the money will be derived from the industries of Australia.

A peculiar paragraph in the Governor-General's speech is that which reads : - "A bill to make better provision for the control of gold reserves in the Commonwealth will be submitted to you." I have not heard that there is anything wrong with the control of gold reserves in Australia, although I have read many financial statements by banking companies and the chairmen of directors of various financial institutions. I have studied many of the cricitisms of both governmental and private financial institutions; but nowhere have I seen any suggestion that there is anything wrong with the position in relation to our gold reserves. What is behind this cryptic utterance in the Governor-General's Speech? Does the Government mean to use the printing press? That appears to be the meaning of the paragraph. I warn the Government that if it tampers with the gold reserves in that way the troubles which confront Australia to-day will be accentuated. Not only would it create further unemployment, but it would also increase prices, raise the cost of production, and deal a deadly blow at the industries of this country. A government which tampered with the gold reserves by issuing more paper money would be like children in a powder magazine; it would be playing with the most dangerous thing to be. found in the legislative arsenal.
The speech contains the following extraordinary paragraph : -

quote.para: Owing to reduction in the price oi wool, the prospects of an unfavourable wheat harvest and other causes, the Commonwealth is faced with a difficult period. These causes, important as they are in our economic life, arc, however, seasonal in character.

speech.para: Is it true that a reduction in the price of wool is seasonal in character? The speech continues -

quote.para: There is no reason to believe that n continuance of these conditions is likely, am i there should be a return to normal prosperity in the coming year. In the meantime, tinpublic revenues of the Commonwealth uri- being adversely affected.

speech.para: If that were the only ill effect of the reduction in the price of wool, the position would not 'be so serious as it really is, but not merely our public revenues, but our private revenues as well, artbeing adversely affected. That means that the fund from which wages are paid is being adversely affected. Wheat and wool are our two staple products, and the money received for them supplies the bulk of the wages fund from which labour is paid in Australia. Although they know that these are the facts, the reported utterances of Ministers lead us to believe that these two industries, reduced as they are in income, will be still further hit by some of the proposals contemplated by the Government.
I propose to conclude my references to the Speech of the Governor-General, by directing attention to the following paragraph : -

quote.para: My Ministers look forward to the Imperial and Economic Conferences to be held next year with the sincere hope that they will be able to co-operate with His Majesty's Government in Croat Britain to the lasting benefit of the Commonwealth of Australia and of the other members of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

speech.para: I ask them, when they meet the representatives of the British Government at the Imperial and Economic Conferences, not to expect Great Britain to make all the concessions; to remember that there is something due from Australia. They must not expect Great Britain to keep up her navy and her army and to continue expenditure upon the Singapore naval base while we in Australia disarm, and render the people of this country unfit to defend themselves. I urge them to remember that, if they expect the British taxpayer to do his bit in regard to effective defence of the Empire, the people of Australia should be prepared likewise to do their part in providing for the defence of this country. I ask them also not to expect the British Government to extend sympathy and assistance to our industries by way of preferential duties while we pile up duties against the British manufacturers who are seeking a market for their goods in this country. I remind them that it will be a very bad introduction to the Imperial and Economic Conferences if they endorse the statement made by the present Minister for Customs (Mr. Fenton) the other day, that this Government intends to build up a tariff wall so high as to prevent the introduction into Australia of all goods that can be manufactured here - in other words, to prevent Britain from finding a market for any of her manufactures in the Commonwealth. I ask them to remember that the British preferential duties in regard to Australian sugar, wine and dried fruits, as well as many other primary products are of substantial benefit to Australia; they are helping to keep many people of this country in employment. If we expect Britain to grant concessions to Australia, we must in return, be prepared to show some consideration for British manufactures.

Honorable senators on this side will give government measures fair criticism and fair treatment. "We shall not take advantage of the fact that we have the numbers, and so we shall not act in any partisan spirit. I can promise the Leader of the Senate that while honorable senators on this side will exercise to the full their right to review legislation, their criticism of Government measures will not be offered in any partisan spirit.

Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW (Queensland) [8.35]. - After the speech delivered by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Sir George Pearce) it is not necessary for me to traverse much of the ground covered by the speech of the Governor-General. I wish, however, to direct particular attention to the Ministry's proposals for the defence of Australia as they affect the activities of the department over which I had the honour to preside as a member of the late Government. Compulsory military training was introduced by legislative act, and it has now been discontinued by an administrative act. We all know what would have been said by supporters of the present Government if the Bruce-Page administration, without reference to Parliament, had introduced any change in policy on such an important subject as the defence of Australia.

talk.start.para: - Is it not a fact that the previous Government, by administrative action, suspended compulsory military training in certain country districts ?

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW.Yes, but that was done for reasons of economy. It was found impossible economically to provide the staff and equipment for the training of youths in certain isolated country districts.

talk.start.para: - Then it is all a question of cost after all.

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon W Kingsmill

talk.start.para: - Order! I remind the Senate that the speech of an honorable senator cannot consist of a series of interrogations and answers. The Leader of the Senate will have an opportunity to reply at a later stage. It will tend materially to shorten the debate if this rule is observed.

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW.I challenge the statement that this Government had a mandate to interfere with the defence policy of this country. At the general election in November of last year, the Nationalist Government stated definitely that it stood for the maintenance of compulsory training as part of its defence policy, and that Ministry was returned with a majority. The election a few weeks ago was fought on an entirely different issue. I admit that the Leader of the Government (Mr. Scullin) intimated that the Labour party stood to its former policy, but the only issue before the people concerned federal arbitration. It is inconceivable that the people within twelve months would change their mind on such a vital subject as the defence policy of Australia as it has existed for eighteen or nineteen years.
SenatorRae. - Will you take us to the country on that issue and see whether the people will endorse it?

talk.start.para: - Order ! Again I remind the Senate that it is not necessary or advisable for questions to be asked while an honorable senator is speaking.

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW.We are informed that it is the Government's intention to retain the present military organization which consists of four infantry divisions, two cavalry divisions and three mixed brigades. To maintain this strength it will be necessary to enlist a certain number of men, and experience has proved that it is not possible to secure them under the voluntary system.

talk.start.para: - That system provided 360,000 men for the war at all events.

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW.But the organization was built up under the compulsory system. What is the history of the defence organization of Australia? Prior to federation our defence forces consisted of volunteers and militia organised in small units in different parts of thecountry. One of the principal reasons for federation was that we should be able to establish a co-ordinated system of defence. Immediately following federation defence was taken over by the Commonwealth. At that time the units had to be raised where the men were prepared to volunteer, and because of the weakness of that system no regard could he paid to the strategic needs of the country. In 1910, the Cook Government commissioned the late Lord Kitchener, the greatest military organizer in the British Empire, to investigate and report upon the defence organization of the Commonwealth, and in his comprehensive report Lord Kitchener recommended that to provide for the defence needs of Australia it would be necessary to introduce compulsory military training. Shortly after that report was received the Cook Government was defeated. The Fisher Government came into office, and, be it said to the credit of that Labour Administration, it gave effect to Lord Kitchener's recommend'ation. Thus it came about that a Labour government introduced compulsory military training in Australia, a system which provided the necessary officers, and noncommissioned officers for the various units sent from the Commonwealth at the com mencement of the war. Hitherto it has been the proud boast of the Labour party that it was responsible for compulsory military training in this country. It was also the proud boast of the Labour party, led by the late Mr. Fisher, that Australia was in the war to the last man and the last shilling, and certain members of the party handed in a blank cheque on both those promises. It is interesting to recall what the present Prime Minister (Mr. Scullin) said in the second-reading debate on the Defence Bill of 1910. His remarks are to be found on page 6218 of Hansard of 16th November, 1910. Mr. Scullin said -

quote.para: The Government are to be congratulated on their courage in providing for universal training with a minimum of inconvenience to those concerned.

speech.para: That was a most commendable statement for a responsible member of this legislature to make.

Let us now examine the situation and test the courage of the Prime Minister to-day. It is apparent that the Government did not contemplate making this drastic change immediately, as the Minister for Defence (Mr. A. Green) is reported in the Melbourne Argus of the 26th October as having stated that - . . No alteration in routine or policy would be made without careful consideration, and the advice of every responsible officer would be welcome. A definite defence policy has not yet been evolved by the Ministry. For the present, the existing conditions in the department would not be disturbed. . . . The Ministry has not discussed the abolition of military training, and it will be months before this question becomes a matter for discussion. When the more pressing problems have been dealt with, we will make a comprehensive review of the defence policy.

Apparently that announcement was made by the Minister with the approval of the Government. The honorable member for Ballarat (Mr. McGrath) is also reported in the Argus of the 29th October in the following way: -

quote.para: Ballarat, Monday. - Mr. McGrath referred to-night to a statement by the new Minister for Defence that the Ministry had not yet. given consideration to its policy concerning compulsory military training. Mr. McGrath said that Mr. Green should know well that the abolition of compulsory training' had always been_ a fundamental plank in the Laborer party's platform, and his statement therefore was. certainly ill-advised. Compulsory military training would vanish before Christmas.

speech.para: In this instance, it is a case of "the tail wagging the clog." One of the recruits has been effectively instructing the officers what they should do in the matter of defence. It is difficult to reconcile both statements. The Minister for Defence accepted full responsibility for the statement he made concerning the defence policy of the Government; but within three days his utterances were contradicted by a member of the party who is not a Minister. The opinion of the member of the Labour party which I have quoted is sufficient to show that the Government lias been influenced by the extremists in that party who have their minds always on Moscow, where, I may remind them, there is plenty of compulsion, particularly in the matter of military training. By administrative act the Government has suspended military training. Why has this course been adopted?

talk.start.para: - To fall into line with the other dominions.
- That is not so. Is it because the system is too costly, that it is ineffective, or does the Government consider that it is wrong in principle?
- Because it is wrong in principle.

- Does the honorable senator realize that in this great democracy in which we are privileged to live every adult has a voice in the government of the country, and thus enjoys the full privileges of citizenship. Those who enjoy such privileges should accept their share of the responsibility for the defence of the country. As the Defence Act provides that it is the responsibility of every able-bodied man between the ages of 16 and 60 to take up arms in defence of his country, should it be necessary, it is the duty of the Government to see that every able-bodied man is given an opportunity to undertake military training to enable him to serve his country should the occasion arise.
- The next war will be one in which science will play a most important part, and man and gun power will be of little value.

- We have heard that statement on numerous occasions. In this instance it is made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is a member of a Cabinet not a single member of which has the slightest knowledge of defence matters. I say unhesitatingly that if there should unfortunately be another international conflict, man power will still be the deciding factor. In suspending compulsory military training the Government has absolutely failed in its duty, it has been recreant to its trust.
- The honorable senator believes in conscripting youths before they have reached the age at which they are entitled to vote.

- Although youths cannot vote until they reach the age of 21 years, they enjoy many of the privileges of citizenship before .reaching that age, and undergo the initial period of their training at a time when it is not likely to seriously interfere with the commercial or other activities in which they may' be engaged.

speech.para: As it has been stated that compulsory military training is more costly than th: volunteer system, it is interesting to notethat in 1908-09, the last year in which provision was made for meeting the expenditure under the voluntary system, the amount provided on the Estimates under this heading was £723,46% whereas for the year 1929-30 provision was made for the expenditure of £1,428,271. In the earlier period which I mentioned, a citizen force establishment of 23,794, militia and volunteers, was provided for, whereas the citizen force establishment for 1929-30 is 50,000. Taking into consideration the decreased purchasing power of money, the £1,428,271 which was recently provided for is equivalent to approximately £900,000 in 190S-09. Considering that the citizen force is practically twice as strong as it was in 1908-09, it is clear that the compulsory system is less costly than the voluntary method, particularly when we remember that the present day organization is more complex and that it contains a larger percentage of specialized units and technical equipment, than was the case some years ago. Under the voluntary system the period of enlistment was for only three years, but not more than 50 per cent, of the men remained in the forces for- eighteen months. This meant in many cases that they were provided with uniforms which were used for only a few months. Attendances were irregular, and the time of the officers and instructional staff was too frequently taken up with parades of insufficient strength. There was, moreover, no regular turnover of men who could be regarded as reserves. Some of the enthusiasts remained in their units for long periods, and performed excellent service, but on the other hand, many others became ineffective after their first camp, when the novelty of soldiering had worn off. Further, under the compulsory system the men can be trained at places which are of strategic importance; it also provides a means of getting the men to attend parades. Some honorable senators who have served in the various units, will be able to speak of the excellent spirit that exists in the Citizen Forces. There has never been a larger number of officers and noncommissioned officers than there are at present; the total now exceeds 10,000. We have never had a larger number of trained officers and non-commissioned officers, and it is absolutely hopeless under the voluntary system to expect to get a sufficient number to keep the present organization going on a voluntary basis. If the Government think that it can do so, it will be disappointed.

talk.start.para: - What did General Sir John Monash say concerning compulsory military training?

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW.I am satisfied that he will be very disappointed to find that the system is being suspended.

talk.start.para: - He said it was an expensive farce.

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW.I do not recall General Monash ever having made such a statement. There are in this chamber honorable senators with military service who will readily admit that it is anything but an expensive farce. Under the present system there is a regular intake of recruits and a regular output of men, who have undergone training in a systematic manner over a definite period at a minimum of cost. That the system is not ineffective is clearly shown by the results achieved during the Great War. The Naval Board reported that, from a naval viewpoint, the system proved the reverse of ineffective, and that after only three years experience of compulsory training the board in 1914 was able to mobilise the numbers required within 24 hours after the declaration of war. On the military side, it may be stated that the success obtained in the organization and training of the Australian Imperial Force was due largely to the existence of a scheme of universal training. At very short notice we were able to mobilise, organize and despatch overseas one division, and a light horse brigade, and these were followed shortly by another division and two light-horse brigades. About a year later we had at the front four infantry divisions and four light horse brigades. That was a wonderful achievement, when we consider that in Australia we had only a citizen force. It was possible only because we enjoyed the benefits of a compulsory military training system. In 1909, the number of officers was only 1,696, but in 1914 there were 3,449.It would be impossible to obtain that number of officers under the voluntary system. Anyone with experience will admit that the compulsory system is the more economic one. Statistics disclose that, under it, it costs only £6 per year to clothe, pay, and train a man. No other system can approach it for economy.

talk.start.para: - Under the voluntary system the uniform alone will cost £6.

speech.para: Senator Sir WILLIAM GLASGOW. That is so. If the Government desired so earnestly to adopt the voluntary system why did it not consult the Council of Defence before taking such a drastic step ?

talk.start.para: - The Council of Defence has no right to fix matters of policy.

- I admit that; but much good would have accrued from such a consultation. I personally could have suggesteda method which would have given the voluntary system a chance: that of continuing the present system for three years, allowing the quota that had served two years to go out next year, the quota with one year's service to go out the following year, and that which had just been called up to go out the third year. Under such a plan and over that period the voluntary system could have been grafted on. to that which has been discarded, and it would have had a chance of success. Instead, as Senator Pearce has said, the Government tinkers with this matter as it has done with many others. It was in such haste to obey the ultimatum that it received from the extremists that it did not consider anybody, not even the Service. Honorable senators on this side keenly regret the action of the Government. This is a matter of high policy which should have been discussed in this chamber before action was taken. One can easily imagine what honorable senators opposite would have said had a Nationalist government followed a similar course.
- I suggest that the honorable senator should take a walk across the King's Hall and visit another place, when he will appreciate the mandate that has been given to this Government.

- Senator O'Halloran knows very well that the recent election was fought on the arbitration issue, and that the change was brought about by the wild and impossible promises made by his party and to-day exposed by Senator Pearce. The Government has acted in a most irresponsible way, without considering the defence needs of the country. Experience has proved that the voluntary system will not give us the necessary men to enable the country to maintain an adequate organization.

speech.para: Further, to indicate how the Government is tinkering with other matters, I quote the following sentence from the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General -

quote.para: The question of maintaining a separate organization for the Air Force having been brought under the notice of my Ministers by officers of the Defence Department, the Defence Committee was instructed to investigate and report to the Council of Defence.

speech.para: Who are the officers of the department who have brought the matter under the notice of Ministers? What a remarkable statement to record in the Governor-General's Speech! And no decision was arrived at by the council! Naturally, Australia cannot at present afford a large air force. That force may have a threefold role. It might be ordered to adopt an independent role, or it might be ordered to co-operate with the army or the navy. It is essential that we should have one co-ordinated Air Force. As the navy now exists that arm of the service would - require about fifteen planes. Surely the Government does not seriously contemplate the creation of a separate service with its own organization and training establishments to provide the necessary services for such a small number of planes? When I was Minister for Defence I went thoroughly into the problem and satisfied myself that the most economical way to train this arm to provide for our defence needs was to have one homogeneous air force. In the event of trouble it would be possible for such a force to play an independent role or to act in cooperation with the army or the navy. In the latter case, it would come under the orders of the commander of the army or the navy. I hope that the Government is not going to cut our diminutive Air Force into separate distinct entities for the army and the navy. The Governor-General's Speech continues on this subject -

quote.para: My Ministers have, however, asked for a report on the possibilities -of co-ordinating the work of the Air Force with that of Civil Aviation

speech.para: The roles of the Air Force and Civil Aviation are absolutely different and distinct. In civil aviation the motto should be " Safety first ", and every pilot who flies a commercial plane should see that he adopts that motto. But a war-plane pilot is taught all sorts of evolutions in the air, as it is only by being expert in aerobatics that he has a chance of victory when he joins issue with an enemy plane. That is why one sees army pilots performing all sorts of evolutions in the air, apparently, to the uninitiated, for amusement. I do not think that it would be wise for the Government to amalgamate the functions of Civil Aviation with those of the Air Force.

Again, the late Nationalist Government always let contracts for the various civil aerial services and the establishment * of different air routes. This Government would be well advised to continue that policy. I suggest that before honorable senators opposite plunge into government enterprises they should take a trip te my State, Queensland, and inquire into the experiences of the State Labour Government in that regard. That information would be of considerable value not only to them, but to the Commonwealth, as it would save the community a very heavy and futile expenditure of public money. Civil aviation is merely another and a new means of transport, and I had contemplated advising the late Government to bring it under the administration of the Minister for Transport. I make the suggestion to the present Government, as it would enable them properly to coordinate the various means of transport. Just as we do not wish to see roads running in competition with railways, so we do not wish to see an air force competing where a very efficient and expeditious land service is already established. The Federal Nationalist Government established commercial air services over routes in the back country of Queensland and Western Australia, and from the latter State to the Eastern States, through Adelaide to Cootamundra and Melbourne. Not only did that policy assist civil aviation, but at the same time it enabled people in our remote centres to make contact with our more densely populated areas. I should like the Government to pause, before taking any further drastic action such as it has adopted in regard to defence. That step is a serious blow to Australia, and I am satisfied that before many years pass it will have to be retraced.

talk.start.para: . - I have carefully perused the Governor-General's Speech, and have come to the conclusion that it is to be distinguished from all others which I have heard in this chamber by reason of the omissions from it. It is difficult to find in it one specific statement; where a subject is mentioned it is in the most vague and general terms. Apparently the Government is afraid to pin itself down to a. definite policy on any subject at all. For example, I have failed to find in the speech, the slightest reference to a matter which has been mentioned definitely in every other Governor-General's Speech since I entered this chamber: that of preference to returned soldiers. I ask the Government to define its attitude in that respect. Is it going to cast that principle overboard as it has done with many others?
- The Nationalist Government honored the principle more in the breach than the observance.
- My party always honored the principle of preference to returned soldiers.
- What about the returned soldiers on the Port Adelaide wharves, who were dismissed and replaced by 147 Europeans.

- Even returned soldiers have to obey the law of the land. If they refused to work on the wharves naturally others had to take their place. However, I leave Senator O'Halloran to settle that matter with his State authorities. The Federal Government did not employ those returned soldiers. I reiterate that my party has always consistently observed the principle of preference to returned men, and since it is reported that that vital principle has been abandoned I should like to have a statement one way or the other from the Leader of the Government in the Senate. If the Government intends to abandon the principle, where did it receive its mandate?

speech.para: With Senator Sir William Glasgow, I regret exceedingly the abolition of compulsory military training. Can any honorable senator point to anything in Mr. Scullin's policy-speech which would give the slightest indication that it was the intention of the Labour party to abandon the principle of compulsory military training. The only mention of the subject of defence in his policy speech was the cryptic reference he made to the adequate defence of Australia which could he construed to mean anything from a regular army downwards? Of course, Ministers will say, " We are merely suspending compulsory training. We do not propose to alter the act, and at any time it is open to any one. to restore compulsory training by a stroke of the pen." If Ministers are convinced of the necessity for this policy, let them bring in a bill to abolish compulsory military training. We are prepared to give them a chance to get a mandate from the people on it. It has been said here to-day that the Ministry consulted its experts before making this change of policy. The statement is absolutely incorrect. A public announcement was made by Mr. Scullin to clear Sir John Monash and Sir Harry Chauvel of the charge that otherwise might very well have been laid against them - that of having advised this change of policy. They made it very clear to Mr. Scullin that that must not on any account be said of them. Two of the greatest living soldiers to-day, who could have been consulted before this change of policy was brought about, were not consulted.

talk.start.para: - They had no right to be consulted in regard to a change of policy.
- The policy announced by the party was the adequate defence of Australia, and not the abolition of compulsory military training.
- The policy announced was clearly and definitely the abolition of. compulsory military training.

- I hope that the honorable senator will point out to me any such statement in Mr. Scullin's policy-speech. It is true that it is in the Labour party's platform; but in Victoria we have been accustomed to hearing Mr. Hogan say, "We do not mind what is in the platform; that is only for the groundlings. This is what we are going to do this session."
- "When did he say that ?
- On the last occasion ou which he was returned he said, " That is all right for the wharfies; but I am not the kind of man to bring in any wild schemes."
- Can the honorable senator name any place where Mr. Hogan made that statement, or give the date on which it was made?
- I can get the information for the honorable senator.

speech.para: Sir John Monash and Sir Harry Chauvel have complained that the policy of compulsory military training was jeopardized by the economy forced by the late Government. They said to the late Government, " You have cut it to the bone until it is verging on extinction."

talk.start.para: - The late Government spent all the money, and now the present Government is expected to retrieve the position.
- The nucleus was much reduced.
- If it is useless, let us abolish it.

- It would be understandable if the Government said, " We have cut down compulsory military training to such an extent that it is useless, and we might as well abolish it." But the present Government has cut down the system still further so that we have it no longer the nucleus of an army. It must not be imagined that by some magic an efficient army can be produced in a day or two from an insignificant nucleus. Sir John Monash and Sir Harry Chauvel were brought into a room and told that the question of compulsory military training had already been decided and must not be discussed, and that they must produce something in its stead. Was that a fair way in which to treat experts?
- Why not? It is their job.

- It is their job to tell us how best to defend Australia. The only task the Government set them was to -find some sort of substitute for what had been abolished. I hope, therefore, honorable senators opposite will not endeavour to camouflage the issue and lay the blame on these experts in order to save their own skins. Why did not Ministers ask these distinguished military gentlemen for a straightout opinion as to the best way in which Australia could be defended? Had they done so they would have got a straightforward recommendation, and the Government could then have decided whether to follow it out or not. It is ray opinion that the nucleus we had could not be further reduced without paralysing its usefulness. We can, of course, decide to have one or two divisions. Ministers say that they propose to maintain five divisions, yet they cut down the nucleus to about half the number of men previously in training. It is a matter of impossibility. Our forces were cut to the bone before. i am awaiting with interest the full proposals of the Government. I am by no means a militarist. In my first term in Parliament I fought against the proposal of the then government to put trainees into camp for three months, and with the help of Senator Gardiner, I fought against the proposal to apply the provisions of the British Army Act to tha Australian forces in time of peace. My object has always been to ensure the adequate defence of Australia and I can assure honorable senators, with all my experience and reputation, that what the present Government proposes will not provide that adequate defence.
- Does the honorable senator think that the Australian "War Council would know anything about the matter? «
- The Government did not give that Council an opportunity to offer an opinion on the subject.
- I think it did.
- I should be glad indeed if the Assistant Minister were in a position to assure us that that was done.

speech.para: Senator Hoare has interjected that during the recent war, with a little training, Australia produced the finest soldiers in the world. Nothing could be further from the truth. I was a soldier during the Boer war and from the outbreak of the last war until its finish, and I can assure the honorable senator that he is totally incorrect. I enlisted in the first week of the Great "War and was appointed to the command of a battalion at Broadmeadows. I had the pick of the officers and noncommissioned officers who came to us under the compulsory training system, and I was ordered to enlist trained men only. I was given the northern . district of Victoria in which to enlist them, and finding that I could not secure the requisite numbers of trained men there I enlisted any likely man that came along. Colonel McCay told me that I had not obeyed orders. I admitted that I had not done so, but asked to be given three weeks in which to train the men I had enlisted, and offered to discharge at the end of that time any man he could pick out as not having had previous ex perience. At the end of the three weeks, Colonel McCay had a parade, but he could not pick out one man who had not had previous training. He said to me, as honorable senators have said to-day, " What is the use of our compulsory training? We spend thousands of pounds on it yet in three weeks you can produce men equal to those who have previously been trained." I replied that I could not have done it but for the fact that I had been given the choice of the experts to take charge of the untrained men. Nevertheless, those men were not even then to be regarded as soldiers. They had merely a veneer of the soldier. That was about the end of August. Steady training was continued until the middle of October, with drill every day and even at night. The men were drilled all the way to Egypt and when they arrived there on the 6th December they were drilled morning, noon and night in the desert until the following April when we set off for Gallipoli and delivered the attack that made the name of Australia famous. Even then these men were not trained soldiers. Had they at that time acquired the absolute mastery of the art of war which they had gained by 1918 when I led them at Villiers-Brettouneux, their casualties would have been nothing compared with what they were at the landing. They attempted to do things which in France they would have recognized as impossible or as requiring other means of achievement. They were the First Division, a body of absolutely picked men, the cream of Australia, whose appearance and intelligence were favourably commented 'upon by every one who came in contact with them, but at the end of nine months they were still raw. It is said by Senator Daly that war is becoming more scientific. Of course it is, but that does not mean that soldiers can do without training. *As a matter of fact it means that they require more training. The greatest advocate of a mechanized army, Major Liddell Hart, is of the opinion that by reason of the scientific training required all armies should now consist of regular soldiers.

talk.start.para: - What is wrong with training soldiers for peace?

- Unfortunately people like the Kaiser insist on having war and in those circumstances what can a man do? I had no wish for war, but when Mr. Andrew Fisher sent along and said, " Colonel, your men are wanted. Will you put up a notice and ask for volunteers?" I did the one thing it seemed possible for me to do in those days. I put my name on the top and said, "Boys, who is coming with me ?" I find that most of the people who are so enthusiastic in asking for a volun tary system are those who want the other fellow to volunteer.

speech.para: SenatorO'Halloran. - Was that the experience of other dominions where conscription does not operate?

talk.start.para: - During the war, conscription operated in every dominion.
- To-day it does not operate in any dominion except Australia and New Zealand.
- Canada maintains a regular army. It is small but it is efficient. It also has in the mounted police a very fine cavalry body. We have nothing.
- After an expenditure of £60,000,000?

- All that we had has been abolished by this Government. Will the honorable senator and his friends go out into the suburbs and ask men to join up at 4s. a day? It is all right to do so when every one must undergo a certain course of training. Then it is right to expect each man to make some sacrifice. But it is quite a different matter to ask a man to volunteer to train himself so that he may be fit to defend his country at the rate of 4s. a day.
- Under a volunteer system a man need not do it if he does not like it.

- Then the alternative is to leave the country open to the first comer. In the event of enemy forces landing on our shores, who would be expected to meet them? Would it be the men who had voluntarily enlisted?
- That would be better than sending boys to meet them.

- A boy who has been trained does not forget his training when he receives his discharge. Many of the present officers in our citizen forces long ago completed their compulsory training. But they cannot maintain their efficiency unless they have material to train.
- The men who went from Australia to the great war, and did so well, were all volunteers.

- Even with officers like Sir John Monash - one of the finest brains in the army - we found that we could not train men in nine months. Sir John Monash started his military career as a volunteer. He built up a splendid library, and attained to the highest rank by his own efforts.
- He is a fine product of the volunteer system.

- During recent years, the course of training has been made so interesting that the trainees are keen to continue it. In a democratic community it is not right that only those who volunteer should undertake the defence of the country.
- Both Sir John Monash and the honorable senator himself were volunteers. What better products of the volunteer system could we have?

- Had it not been for the compulsory training of preceding years we could not have done what we did in the war. Australia's wonderful effort there was the result of the compulsory training system; the Australian Imperial Forces were the product of the compulsory training system. Had we attempted to bring a whole army into being at once, as the Americans did, we should have failed utterly. That country already had a regular army; its material was as good as ours; but they were entirely ignorant of the rudiments of war, even after fifteen months' training in their own country. At the battle of Hamel they were sandwiched between our own men, and they performed magnificently; but later, when they went into action alone, they were not only defeated, but massacred. The men were the same as our own - they were good men - but they were untrained. We built up our force gradually, using the trained men to instruct the others. It was not done in a day, and, while we were training, the first volunteer army was sacrificed. The sacrifice of the " Old Contemptibles " saved civilization.
- Sir John Monash described as farcical the system until recently in operation.

- The honorable senator knows how easy it is to create a false impression by a newspaper article. I have read the newspaper report of Sir John Monash's remarks, and I know to what he referred. It is true that he said we did not have an army; but when the distinguished general said that he was referring to the policy of retaining the nucleus of an army instead of an army. He said that, as an army, that nucleus was useless ; but our finances at the time were such that we could not maintain more than a nucleus. I challenge the Leader of the Government to ask Sir John Monash to compare the Government's new proposal with the system which it supersedes. At the time when our soldiers were winning world-wide praise, the party to which Senator Daly belongs declared publicly that it was folly to send any more Australians overseas, because the few thousand men that we could put into the field would not be more than as a spoonful of water in the ocean compared with the vast masses already there. I do not say that the Australian soldiers won the war; but I refer with all modesty to the words of the great enemy general, Ludendorf, who said that it was the allied victory of the 8th August, 1918, which convinced him that Germany had lost the war. That victory was won by the Australians under Sir John Monash. The force under his control was greater than that which comprised the whole British Army at Waterloo. So great was the faith of the Allied leaders in Sir John Monash that a force of Canadians equal to the Australian force in numbers was placed under his command. The Labour party at that time would have robbed the Allies of the momentous victory which the Australians won on that occasion. So long as Australia maintains even the nucleus of an army like that which fought in the late war, other nations will hesitate to challenge it; but, unfortunately, the Government has announced its intention to abolish the system which built up that army, and to substitute for it something which might in future bring the Australian soldier into contempt. While every officer of the force will do his best to make a success of the new scheme, that success will not be attained unless the Government itself urges the citizens of this country to fill the empty ranks, and make the army a live concern. The Labour party, however, contains men who would leave Australia defenceless.
- There is a minority in every political party, including that to which the honorable senator belongs, which would do that.

- The- reason for the Government's proposal is difficult to understand, seeing that it has admitted that it is not made on the ground of economy. Indeed, it proposes to spend even more money, not on schools of instruction, but on what are comparative frills. It will provide prettier uniforms for the volunteers. Should the men of Scottish extraction insist on being provided with kilts, the additional expense will be considerable. If the Government and its supporters were frank, they would admit that they have no desire whatever to take any part in the defence of the Empire. One would think that the United States of America, being separated by many miles of sea from any possible enemy, would not build up any considerable military force, but that country is not adopting that policy. President Hoover has been enthusiastically quoted as a leading exponent of the doctrine that countries, such as Australia, can purchase immunity from invasion by disarming, and so shaming warlike neighbours into disarming, too. His Armistice Day speech shows that he does not share this infatuation. He said -

quote.para: The world is at peace, but it is an armed peace. Including active reserves there are nearly 10,000,000 more men under arms than there were at the outbreak of the war in 1914, and there are fears, distrusts and smouldering injuries amongst the nations which are the tinder of war. Nor does anything in human experience warrant the assumption that war cannot occur again. We must reduce and limit warships by agreement only. I have no faith in reduction of armaments by example alone. Until the nations can build agencies for the pacific settlement of disputes on stronger foundations, until fear has been proved groundless by long proof of international honesty, until the power of world public opinion as a restraint of aggression has had many years' test, there will not have been established that confidence which warrants the abandonment of preparedness for defence amongst the nations. To do so may invite war.

speech.para: Dohonorable senators supporting the Government wish to invite war in Australia in the years to come?

talk.start.para: - Is it not a fact that the United States of America is about the most jingoistic country in the world?

- That may be so; but I have no doubt that the people of the United States of America have some basis for their fear. And who is to say that one day that country will not deem it expedient to invade Australia? Prior to the war the United States of America possessed 10 dreadnoughts, 23 cruisers, 42 destroyers, and 23 submarines. Last year, despite the Washington naval agreement, that country had 18 dreadnoughts, 32 cruisers, 262 destroyers, and 122 submarines - an enormous increase on the pre-war figures. It has a regular army of 134,500 men and 180,000 militia. It proposes to raise the latter figures to 435,000. In addition, it has 112,000 in the reserve officers' training corps, comprising university graduates and other highly-educated men who, after their ordinary military training, are placed in a special reserve.
- We see some of those in the pictures.

- No doubt they get good training in sham fights, and are photographed in the process. Senator Dooley said this afternoon that in its defence proposals this Government was keeping pace with the times. I invite him now to say with what country are we keeping pace. I heard some reference to Denmark's proposal to disarm. On that subject I addressed a question to the honorary minister (Senator Barnes) today, and I was told that the official information will be obtained for me. In the course of my military duties I get information of this nature and I know that the Government of Denmark never proposed to dispense entirely with its army. Although it intends to abolish compulsory military training, it will retain its 25,000 regular troops at their full strength. We should remember also that Denmark has an area about equal to that of Gippsland in Victoria, or the Federal Capital Territory, and I suggest that a regular army of 25,000 men is ample for its defence.

speech.para: Its harbours, I presume, are well guarded by submarines. It cannot be suggested that the position of Denmark is analogous to that of Australia. This country offers a much richer prize for an aggressor nation. It would appear from its declaration of policy, that if Great Britainbecame involved in war, the aim of the present Government would be to maintain neutrality in Australia.

talk.start.para: - I hope so.

- Well, that is a useful admission to have. When we went away at the outbreak of the war, the party which the honorable senator is now supporting declared that Australia was in the war to the last man and the last shilling. We left Australia with that promise ringing in our ears, but when we were almost at our last gasp a certain section of the Labour party failed to live up to its promise. Disguise it as they may, the Government and its supporters are under the domination of the Red Internationale, which regards Great Britain as its greatest foe. At present the Red Internationale is raising a revolt among the natives in South Africa and is doing its best to cause trouble in India. It is endeavouring to white ant the British Empire in the hope that one day it will tumble down in ruins, and it seems that this Government is prepared to give these enemies of our Empire its full support. My career as a soldier is rapidly coming to a close, and I do not wish to see Australia's sons with naked hands in the face of some enemy. Possibly a son of Senator Dunn may one day be in that unhappy position.
- God forbid.
- I am with the honorable senator in that wish. That is why I am protesting against the defence policy of the Government.

speech.para: I turn now to the John Brown prosecution. That was another confidence trick planned by the Labour party on the Australian public. The present Government even got Mr. Maxwell " in the bag," for he went about declaring the iniquity of the Bruce-Page Government for failing to prosecute Mr. John Brown. To-day the Leader of the Senate (Senator Daly) admits that, after all, it is a matter of pure law - that he is unable to say whether or not Mr. Brown was guilty of an offence.

He knows that as a matter of pure law, Mr. Brown has been guilty of no offence. Recently, in the Melbourne Argus, I had an interesting discussion on this subject with Colonel Crouch, a member of the Labour party, who, like myself, is a lawyer. My final contribution to the controversy was an offer of £50 to the funds of any industrial union named by Mr. Crouch if he could produce the opinion of any K.C. practising in Melbourne - this offer included Mr. Maxwell, K.C. - who was prepared to say that there was a clear case against Mr.. Brown. I agree with the Leader of the Senate, that the issue involved is a question of law, and a very difficult one, too. But the honorable gentleman did not stress this fact when he was in opposition. He contented himself with decrying the action of the Government in withdrawing the prosecution.

talk.start.para: -We objected to the withdrawal of the prosecution after it had been launched.

- The honorable gentleman knows that prosecutions are withdrawn every day of the week. The Crown, if it is satisfied after further investigation that no offence has been committed, enters a nolle prosequi.
- In the John Brown case, the Attorney-General did not say he was satisfied that no offence had been committed.
- Well, the Leader of the Senate now has all the papers. If he is satisfied that an offence was committed,I invite him to launch a prosecution now.
- The Bruce-Page Government withdrew the prosecution against the advice of the Attorney-. General.

speech.para: SenatorH. E. ELLIOTT. - Well, that advice stands, so why not carry on and prosecute ?

talk.start.para: - We will get him in another way.

- We all know, of course, that the attack on the Bruce-Page administration over the John Brown prosecution, was only part of the scheme of misrepresentation that was such a marked feature of the whole election campaign.

speech.para: As a final instance of hypocrisy on the part of the Government and its supporters, I propose to quote an interesting document, which I think should be placed on record in Hansard. Every one knows that the appellation "digger" is regarded as an honorable one by every Australian soldier. No one thought of claiming the term as an exclusive privilege, but a certain gentleman, it appears, considered that he had a better right to it than anybody else. I have here a copy of a document from the RegistrarGeneral's office in New South Wales. It reads as follows: -

quote.para: Know all Men by these Presents that i the undersigned James Patrick Digger Dunn of Kempsey in the State of New South Wales Engine Driver and now or lately called James Patrick Dunn Do Hereby on behalf of myself and my heirs and issue lawfully begotten absolutely adopt and assume the additional christian name of" Digger " and for the purpose of evidencing such additional christian name i Hereby Declare that I shall at all times hereafter in all records deeds documents and other writings and in all actions suits and proceedings as well as in all doalings transactions matters and things whatsoever and upon all occasions use and subscribe the said name of James Patrick Digger Dunn and I therefore hereby expressly authorize and require all persons whomsoever at all times to designate describe and address me as James Patrick Digger Dunn.
In Witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal this fourteenth day of August in the year one thousand nine hundred and twenty eight.
James Patrick Digger Dunn (l.s. )
Signed Sealed and Delivered by the said James Patrick Dunn in the presence of: -

item.label: W.
item.para: H. Sheridan, Solicitor,

debate.para: Kempsey
Registered No. 1185.
Received into the office of the Registrar General the sixteenth day of August one thousand nine hundred and twenty eight.
I suggest that the honorable gentleman could not have been too sure of his right to share in the glory attached to that name, so he took out patent rights for it.

talk.start.para: - I served under you.
- That may be so. I have met many of the men who were under my command during the war. Altogether about 25,000 men passed through my hands.

speech.para: I turnnow to another interesting subject - the statement that southern Europeans are allowed to come to Australia to take work which should be given to Australians, and I propose to show that they are not doing this country any dis-service. In the Gippsland district of Victoria a vast area of fertile hills country was abandoned during the war, because of the inroads of rabbits and the spread of the bracken fern. When our boys came back from the war, those who in the ordinary course would have returned to farms in the hills districts of Gippsland and the Otway Ranges, realized that the country could be reclaimed only as the result of a tremendous expenditure of labour. Furthermore, they were attracted to the city by the illusion of high wages and short working hours, so they drifted off the land, and hundreds of thousands of acres of fertile farm areas were abandoned. To-day southern Europeans are taking up those lands. They are hard at work clearing the country of bracken and rabbits, and are converting the holdings into productive settlements. These men are not depriving anyone of a job, but are only undertaking pioneering work which others who have sought easier conditions in the cities have declined to do. They carry on their task from early morning until nightfall, and are assisted by their womenfolk, just as are many rural workers in France and Italy

talk.start.para: - They are in a different position from those who aro competing with men in the labour market.

- Yes, and for that reason there is no justification for condemning them. I attended school with sons of southern Europeans, some of whom fought in the Australian Imperial Forces overseas. They are good Australian citizens and we should welcome them, particularly as many of them are developing land which others have neglected and in doing so are endeavouring to secure an honest livelihood for themselves and their families. When these diligent men are. reclaiming a wilderness and are not interfering with anyone, why should we term them " dagoes " ? Their sons will make just as good men as the present Treasurer who, believe, is of the same descent. Men should be encouraged to take up this work.
- Do they receive the award rates?

- Award rates do not come into the question, as they are working on their own account just as' are other rural settlers who are operating in a small way in other parts of the Commonwealth. I am not in favour of men being sweated; but men of this type who are assisting the development of this country should be encouraged.
- Are not many of them working for farmers?

- In most -cases, I understand, they have taken up abandoned farms, and in providing for themselves are also rendering a very useful service to the community. It is wrong to assume that every southern European who comes to this' country is a competitor in the labour market, because many of them are undertaking ' work which our own people will not tackle. I am sorry that the Government has submitted such a meagre legislative programme, and in conclusion point out that it is somewhat difficult to learn from the Governor-General's Speech what measures the Ministry actually intends to introduce.
